result.title: Objective
result.description: Increase of energy efficiency in new and renovated residential buildings

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Average thermal energy consumption for space heating in new and renovated buildings

baseline.comment: Average thermal energy consumption for space heating: 140 kJ/m2. °C.day for existing building stock, and 110 kJ/m2. °C.day for new and renovated buildings complying with the current code

target.comment: Average thermal energy consumption for space heating reduced to 80 kJ/m2. °C.day for new and renovated buildings

actual.comment: Official compulsory introduction of new normative technical requirements for energy efficiency in buildings proposed by UNDP / GEF project is expected from July 1, 2015. According to verified data it is expected to decrease the average thermal energy consumption for new and renovated buildings to 83 kJ/(m2°Cd). The project has completed work on the assessment of compliance with the applicable standards of thermal energy consumption in new buildings (by the example of Astana). The assessment results are summarized and described in Outcome 1.1.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: CO2 emissions from energy use in new and renovated buildings

baseline.comment: 25.5 million tonnes of CO2 emitted during 2010-2015 by buildings newly built or renovated during this period

target.comment: 23.5 million tonnes of CO2 emitted during 2010-2015 by buildings newly built or renovated during this period (2 million tonnes less than baseline)

actual.comment:
Baseline: 2.856 mln t CO2 would be emitted from 2010-2015 by the newly constructed and renovated buildings.
Project: 1.9 mln tCO2 will be emitted from 2010-2015 by the newly built and renovated buildings.
Note: having obtained new, more reliable statistical data on the housing sector, and as a result of the calculations made by the project, the base and project lines were adjusted.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: CO2 emissions from energy use in new and renovated buildings

baseline.comment: 186 million tonnes of CO2 emitted from energy use in these buildings over a 25-year lifetime

target.comment: 171 million tonnes of CO2 emitted from energy use in these buildings over a 25-year lifetime (15 million tonnes less than baseline)

actual.comment:
Baseline: 71.4 mln tCO2 would be emitted over a 25-year lifetime by the newly constructed and renovated buildings (2010-2015).
Project: 47.5 mln tCO2 would be emitted over a 25-year lifetime by the newly constructed and renovated buildings (2010-2015).
Note: having obtained new, more reliable statistical data on the housing sector, and as a result of the calculations made by the project, the base and project lines were adjusted.

result.title: OUTCOME 1
result.description: Improved enforcement and implementation of mandatory building energy codes and rating system

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Output 1.1Streamlined and strengthened building energy code enforcement leads to universal compliance with existing codes
Rates of compliance with applicable energy codes

baseline.comment: Baseline compliance rate has not been formally documented; various national experts state that noncompliance is widespread at the construction stage

target.comment: Documented and statistically verified compliance by new buildings, starting in 2012. Whole-building energy consumption targets of 2004 thermal-performance code, supported by field inspection and measurements as well as design data.

actual.comment:
The enforcement system has improved, and the compliance rate to the legislation and the standard-technical documents has increased due to the following conceptual changes with the account of reassignment of the state authorities:
1. In 2014 according to the Law of RK “On amendments and additions to some legislative acts of RK in respect of separation of jurisdictions among levels of state management”, functions of licensing, assessment and control in the sphere of architecture, urban development and construction were transferred to the local executive bodies. It has been determined that the local executive bodies will be responsible for state architecture-building control, quality of construction and would carry out the technical inspection of the builders, and designers supervision of developers’ activity.
2. The system of certification of the experts engaged in the designer-building supervision was improved – a system of certification of the experts engaged in the designer-technical supervision and project expertise was adopted. Starting November 2014, a system of certification of the state construction experts engaged in the architecture-building control and inspection was adopted. More than 6000 of employees have passed certification.
3. The UNDP/GEF project developed test questions on 12 legislative acts and building regulations in the sphere of building and Energy Efficiency. They were successfully used to test knowledge of experts in the given sphere. Starting this August it is planned to use test questions to certify designers. This assessment program will be launched in August 2015 by the Committee for Construction.
4. To improve the system of design expertise and increase the quality of developed design documentation, the Committee for Construction is carrying out a reform of expert activity.
Rules to carry out complex independent expertize of technical, economic justification and design-estimate documentations for the construction of new buildings as well as for renovation and major repairs of existing buildings and constructions. (Order of the Minister of the National economy of the Republic of Kazakhstan No. 229 dated 1 April 2015). These rules set the order of complex independent expertise of the construction projects based on the principle of “One window”. The compulsory expertise of the energy efficiency of the objects is carried out under the framework of independent expertise of projects, organized by the Republican State Enterprise "Gozexpertiza". The Rules are compulsory for all subjects of architecture, urban development and construction on the territory of the Republic of Kazakhstan.
5. According to set rules, the local executive body (Akimat) carries a compulsory energy audit of the buildings before the major repairs in the framework of regional development program (Housing and communal utilities modernization program). According to information from the regions more than 500 energy audits have already been conducted. The buildings with potential energy savings of 15% and higher are subjects to repair. The Book of typicals (by regions), developed by JSC “KazCenterZhKKh” serves as the basis for taking the energy efficient measures for each type of multi-apartment buildings with account of different climatic zones and years of construction.
6. Proposed by UNDP/GEF project, additions to the statistical reports on (1-KS and 2-KS) were introduced into state reporting practice. The Form 2-KS envisions collection of data by the EE class of the built and commissioned buildings, the use of renewable energy sources; Form 1-KS envisions the cost of introduction of “green” activities in the buildings.
7. The UNDP / GEF project developed an express assessment methodology of energy consumption in constructed residential buildings to verify compliance with existing construction norms for energy efficiency. This methodology was tested by the example of Astana.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Output 1.2 New voluntary (recommended) national and/or regional energy efficiency standards for \"green buildings\" lead to implementation of EE beyond existing code requirements
Adoption and implementation of voluntary standards, with verification procedure
Number of buildings complying with voluntary standards

baseline.comment: No voluntary standards for energy performance beyond existing code requirements exist in Kazakhstan

target.comment:
Embodying super-efficient energy performance across various end uses
At least three A-class buildings designed or constructed according to the voluntary standard by the end of the project

actual.comment:
To promote and implement voluntary EE standards and construct more energy efficient buildings (beyond minimum code requirements), the Project finished works on promotion of design and construction of buildings with A-class of Energy Efficiency (the most efficient): developed the promotion concept for such buildings, created labelling (label) for EE class to be placed on the facade of the buildings, Technical Solutions Catalogue for design and operation of high class of EE buildings was prepared and issued. The Catalogue is intended for designers and decision-makers.
The construction of EXPO 2017 objects has started in Astana (exhibition pavilions and residential multi-apartment buildings). These buildings are planned to be built and certified in compliance with standards of ecological assessment.
National companies (JSC “Astana EXPO – 2017”, Fund “Samruk-Kazyna” and “BI Group”) are constructing “green” residential quarters and exhibition pavilions, which, upon completion, will be certified in accordance with the international “green standards” to obtain high marks within the rating systems.
Together with the National Green Building Council (KazGBC), established in 2013 with assistance of UNDP/GEF project, the project is developing the National Standard of Green Buildings in respect of assessment of their efficiency (the assessment includes 15 basic criteria). Work is expected to be finished in August 2015. This standard will be used by National Holding “Fund “Samruk-Kazyna” at project selection for the state construction programs.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
Output 1.3 Adopted revisions to national building energy codes and associated official documents lead to more effective implementation and incremental energy savings
New norms adopted and new required levels of energy efficiency implemented

baseline.comment: Average energy performance requirements for space heating and ventilation according to SN RK 2.04-21-2004* - 141 kWh/m2.year for a 5-floor residential building

target.comment: Average energy performance requirements for space heating and ventilation according to the newly adopted building code SN RK 2.04-04-2011 are nominally 4% higher - 136 kWh/m2.year for a 5-floor residential building

actual.comment:
1. 4 standard-technical documents were developed with the assistance of the UNDP/GEF project, defining the application of national building norms and rules “Thermal Protection of Buildings” and “Heating, ventilation and air-conditioning” with stricter thermal performance and energy consumption requirements for new and renovated buildings: 2 detailed methodological guides and 2 Technical Solutions Catalogues on designing of the EE-based residential buildings. The hand-outs were prepared and issued for free distribution among designers. The Project held presentations of published editions with more than 150 participants.
2. With assistance of UNDP/GEF project, a detailed assessment of the process for design and construction of the residential housing has been carried out (from the project idea to its implementation). Necessary recommendations to improve design and construction process were prepared. The road map for decision-making was developed on their basis which was provided to the Committee for Construction.
The committee for construction received important proposals, taken from the developed roadmap for approval, made by the UNDP / GEF project: a) EE class compliance with the comfort class of the building (will allow building more energy efficient houses with high class of comfort (elite and business class) and avoid building non-EE houses for economy and social class of comfort. B) An obligation to notify about the EE class at the stage of issuing permits for the design of the building (the so-called architectural and design assignment), which will regulate the process of designing of the building with the account of existing energy deficit in some areas.
Due to the tightening of regulatory requirements for energy efficiency of buildings and increase in state control over the progress of the design and construction works in the country as a whole it is expected to increase the energy efficiency of buildings by 15-25%.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
Output 1.4 Rating and labeling system for EE in buildings provides clear information to market stakeholders, as well as a technical basis for financial incentives, leading to increased market demand for energy efficient buildings
Adoption of energy efficiency rating and labeling system

baseline.comment: Energy Passport rating system for buildings is established only on a recommendatory basis by the 2004 code. In practice, this rating system and associated building labels are not being applied

target.comment: Energy Passport rating and labeling system established and applied widely to new and existing buildings in the selected regions primarily and ultimately expanding to a mandatory nationwide basis

actual.comment:
1. Mandatory rating system for energy efficiency in buildings adopted by the Government and Parliament. Specifically, the Law of Kazakhstan “On Energy Saving and Energy Efficiency” adopted in January 2012 envisages a range of energy efficiency measures proposed by the project as follows:
Energy audit concept, rules and requirements
Compulsory energy rating of buildings
Nomination of government and authorized agencies responsibilities for ensuring compliance with the requirements for energy efficiency in design and estimate documentation, construction and renovation
2. For better implementation of adopted EE Law 3 secondary EE by-laws developed by the Project and adopted by Government Resolutions among which
Rules on buildings energy rating determination and review
EE requirements for building designs
EE technology requirements for buildings
According to these Resolutions a particular energy rate of building must be indicated already in Terms of reference for designer.
3. Separate Rules on energy efficiency expertize of design-estimate documentations is adopted with project contribution which ensure examination of energy passport and rating calculation correctness as well as other EE issues.
4. The Concept on transition of the Republic of Kazakhstan to “green” economy was developed and adopted with assistance of the Project. An Action Plan for 2013-2020 was approved by the Government to implement the Concept, envisioning mandatory labelling of all buildings by energy efficiency classes.
5. With the support of UNDP / GEF project, the energy efficiency of the administrative building in the city of Karaganda was assessed. For the first time in the country energy efficiency certificate of the object was made and placed on the facade of the building (class calculations were made on the basis of the new building regulations - SN RK 2.04-04-2011).
6. UNDP / GEF Project prepared proposals to introduce mandatory labeling of energy efficiency of the buildings (text of the Order of the Minister, including the relevant provisions and the design of EE certification). Currently, the Project of the Order of the Minister is being coordinated by the Ministry of Justice of the Republic of Kazakhstan. Within the framework of UNDP / GEF Project it is planned to install energy efficiency certificates on two pilot houses in Astana and Karaganda until the end of 2015 after the publication of the Order of the Minister.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description:
Output 1.5 GHG monitoring and accounting system supports effective project evaluation and helps shape future national priorities for energy efficiency in housing sector
Creation and official adoption of GHG monitoring system and accounting procedures. Number of buildings participating in this new system

baseline.comment: General data about energy consumption in housing sector can be extrapolated from centralized energy supply statistics, but there exists no methodologically uniform system for compiling data on energy use by individual buildings, nor on the effects of energy efficiency measures, a fortiori nor statistics for GHG monitoring from this sector

target.comment:
Official procedures for GHG monitoring and accounting in buildings is developed and applied (based for example on the Energy Passport system of newly re/constructed buildings and on energy audits and metered district heat supply in buildings where available).
90% of newly constructed buildings and 90% of newly reconstructed buildings subject to Energy Passport system in the following 5 years

actual.comment:
1. A major requirement for true monitoring and accounting of the greenhouse gases emissions from the residential buildings sector is presence of thermal energy meters in residential buildings.
As a result of the execution of orders of the President and Government to install heat meters in residential housing in some cities of Kazakhstan (for example, Astana, Semey, and others), the meters were installed for more than 90% of consumers.
The incentive for the installation of meters is differentiated tariff for heating (depending on the presence or absence of heat meters). In some cities (Astana, Karaganda, and others) heat supply companies adopted and implemented investment program to install meters for the consumers (the refund for the installation of heat meters is made through the tariff). In 2015, the government of Kazakhstan has allocated 32.4 million USD for the installation of heat meters to consumers from the republican budget. These funds will be used by heat supply companies as borrowings, which will allow installing meters for more than 50% of consumers.
2. An information system for accounting and monitoring of energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions in the building sector has been developed on the basis of the proposed by UNDP /GEF express methodology. The system was tested by the example of Astana (the city with the highest rate of heat meters installment (90%). This system allows online monitoring of energy consumption of buildings, defining actual EE class of buildings, and greenhouse gas emissions (see Note)
Note: Information about the system of monitoring of energy efficiency and greenhouse gas emissions from the building sector: on-line system is designed to account the consumed resources across the entire city / cities, which buildings are equipped or will be equipped with digital meters of thermal and electric energy. The program includes functions to calculate greenhouse gas emissions from the amount of consumed heat and electricity resources, as well as functions to calculate the class of energy efficiency of the exploited buildings. The developed system will be tested and presented as a pilot in the city of Astana - by autumn 2015.

result.title: OUTCOME 2
result.description: Expansion of markets for energy-efficient products.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Output 2.1 Certification and labeling with regard to energy performance leads to greater consumer understanding and demand for efficient materials and/or products
Establishment of labeling system of selected energy efficiency construction materials/products.Public recognition of labeling and response to given information

baseline.comment: Energy efficiency certification and labeling of products\materials is deficient or absent

target.comment: Labeling system established and applied based on new standards and/or other enhanced procedures. 25% of customers are aware of and understand EE labels. 10% of customers take EE label information into account in their purchasing decisions

actual.comment:
The review of the international experience on construction materials’ certification is accomplished. Energy efficient windows were selected as a product for the development of the standard.
Due to the refusal of the Customs Union on developing standards for window designs, UNDP / GEF project proposed to amend the existing rules of the window designs with account of heat transmission resistance ratio (m2 C / W). Amendments to the rules will increase the requirements for EE of windows by, preliminarily, 100-120%, depending on the climatic region of Kazakhstan, and will allow introducing simple labeling of windows (by heat transmission resistance ratio (m2 C / W). Adoption of the new rules is planned before the end of 2015 after the feasibility analysis and assessment of costs and benefits of introduction of these standards. Preparation for the feasibility analysis is currently being carried out with the assistance of UNDP / GEF project.
To inform the wide range of consumers about the advantages of energy-efficient windows, the UNDP / GEF project has prepared and published a special booklet "How to choose energy-efficient windows?" with a detailed explanation of the existing classification and labeling of windows. The brochure is distributed through the leading window companies.

result.title: OUTCOME 3
result.description: Education and outreach to promote energy-efficient building design and technology

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Output 3.1 Enhanced training enables building designers to apply international best practices in energy-efficient building design and technology
Ability of architects and engineers to design energy-efficient buildings, applying best practices and technology. Number of buildings built embodying practices and technology introduced via enhanced instruction

baseline.comment: Architects and engineers have high technical capabilities and receive some training on energy efficiency, but there is a lack of key information on international best practices, as well as on social, economic, and environmental benefits

target.comment: Enhanced courses on energy efficiency included as a standard part of building-design curricula, delivered to at least 350 building design professionals by the end of the project. International study tour completed for 10-12 participants

actual.comment:
Prototype designs of a prefabricated multiapartment 9 and 5 floor buildings for non-seismic zones were developed and the design document as well as the model of the buildings were presented to implementing Committee for Construction. It is indicated in ToR and expected that energy performance of building will be rated as energy efficient class A or B depending on the climate conditions of construction.
The project was presented at the technical committee meeting at “Samrul Kazyna Real Estate” to be implemented through the mass construction under the state housing program.
To develop industrial housing system design and technology the project with the assistance of Belarus experts organized a seminar for design engineers and architects.
The Project conducted an advanced training in 5 regions of Kazakhstan for the experts of design organizations, state enterprise “Gosexpertiza” and Committee for Construction to enhance the exchange of international experience, discussion of energy efficiency in the design, including calculations under the heading "Energy", an example of filling in design estimates documentation and building energy passport.
Research will be conducted to create and arrange online survey for different participants using SurveyMonkey to measure the effectiveness of educational activities under UNDP project "Energy efficient design and construction of residential buildings''. The result of the research is a report that will be submitted in 3Q 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Ouctome 3: Output 3.2 Competitions motivate building designers to pursue energy-efficient design, and raise collective expertise
Ability of architects and engineers to design energy-efficient buildings, applying best practices and technology.Number of participants and competitive designs

baseline.comment: Motivation to pursue energy-efficient building design is largely driven by market demand. There are no contests or other mechanisms within the design community to stimulate such motivation

target.comment: At least two competitions during the project period on energy-efficient building design, attracting 50 participants

actual.comment:
With technical and financial support of the Project the 6th Multi-Comfort House Contest organized in Kazakhstan in cooperation with Saint-Gobain company, KazGASA, KazNTU, Pavlodar Technical and other Universities. Out of 70 registered participants, 31 arrived as finalists. Prior to the submission of final contest projects the Project held 16 lectures on thermal insulation, acoustic solutions, engineering systems, and green & passive houses etc. The first three awardees took part in an international Multi-Comfort House contest.
In cooperation with Finpro Kazakhstan and the Committee for Construction, Housing and Communal Utilities of RoK the project arranged two seminars in the cities of Astana and Almaty for (more than 80 participants) engineers, architects, designers and other stakeholders dealing with the energy efficiency issues. The main focus was on the exchange of best practices in District Heating, District Cooling and CHP as well as on Energy Efficiency in heat distribution and networks, heating pipe technology and etc.
With the support from the non-governmental organizations (involved into energy and resource saving, housing and communal utilities and construction), the Committee for construction organized and conducted Republican Contest for the design of the energy efficient buildings among the universities undergraduates. 12 works were presented at the Contest, 3 of which, selected by the expert committee, were awarded. The information about the Contest and its outcome was presented through leading mass media.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
Output 3.3 Workshops will give grounds for building owners and developers to build energy effective buildings and effectively to offer them to buyers and renters at the market
Recognition by building owners of the benefits from construction of value of energy effective buildings. Number of workshops
and participants

baseline.comment: Building owners have little interest in construction of energy effective buildings, a primary importance is given to appearance, conveniences and cost reduction

target.comment: At least in three regions of the country (with the most dynamically developed construction sector) the building owners, project customers and developers, construction companies trained and interested to implement energy efficiency in building re/construction. Practical manuals - guides/videos on appropriate practices of energy efficiency installations\\\\technologies\\\\equipment published, at least 400 practitioners trained

actual.comment:
1. More than 1100 participants of 28 project national and regional workshops and seminars (500 designers and construction workers, 400 owners, developers and service companies, 80 architects, 80 energy audit experts, 60 journalists, ) were trained on best practices in the field of the integrated design, energy labeling, green standards, energy audit, energy-efficient technologies and their correct installation.
2. 6 media trainings in the cities of Atyrau, Ust-Kamenogorsk, Kyzylorda, Aktau, Taraz, Shumkent were conducted for 120 kazakh journalists from regional and local mass-media agencies and TV channels. The participants are now aware how to highlight the energy efficiency issues using modern multimedia tools.

result.title: OUTCOME 4
result.description: Development and demonstration of energy-efficient building projects

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Output 4.1
Best practices in design of energy-efficient buildings and technology demonstrated in two residential buildings
Re/construction of buildings embodying the best practices in design of energy-efficient buildings

baseline.comment: New residential buildings in Kazakhstan do not embody international best practices or technology

target.comment: New energy-efficient residential buildings newly re/constructed by the third and fourth years of the project (2013 and 2014). Energy performance and cost-effectiveness of both buildings documented by end of project

actual.comment:
Pilot 1 - EE design and construction of a new pilot building in Karaganda city.
A new pilot building was constructed and put into operation in Karaganda city with the following main characteristics: 10 floors; total area of 17145.3 m2; number of apartments – 170; the expected EE class – “B” (high) Measures on EE improvement were proposed, approved by the State Expertise and executed by the UNDP / GEF project at the design stage of the pilot building. The measures to improve EE were fully executed: additional insulation of the external envelope, installation of energy-saving windows, installation of forced ventilation system with heat recuperation, installation of horizontal heat distribution pipe, apartment-wise regulation and accounting of consumed thermal energy, and centralized dispatching system for heat supply and ventilation. Currently, two-block section are inhabited by tenants, two are uninhabited.
The increase in construction cost due to EE measures is 9.5%, the expected energy savings – up to 35%.
Meanwhile, energy audit of the baseline building in close proximity to Pilot 1 was conducted. The energy audit showed low energy efficiency of the baseline building corresponding to D-class.
The Project initiated energy consumption monitoring of the building and its comparison with the baseline building for the heating season of 2014-2015. The results will be finalized in August 2015.
Pilot 2. Thermal modernization of an old residential building in Karaganda city, Mustafina 26.
The Project contributed through replacement of window blocks with energy-saving blocks having higher heat transmission resistance ratio.
Following completion of thermal modernization, the Project conducted energy audit and analysis of earlier accomplished EE measures. In 2014-2015 a detailed monitoring of thermal energy was conducted. Alongside with other measures on EE improvement of the building (insulation of roof, installation of automated heat supply unit with energy meter, etc.), EE window installment resulted in reduction of thermal energy consumption during a single heating season (statistical average of four heating seasons) by 50 Gcal or 25 % in comparison with a base period (2010-2011). As the result, green house gas emissions reduced by 60 tons, payments for heating supply reduced by 6-10 % in comparison with the base period.
In one heating season the apartment owners were able to collectively save about 840 USD (about 40 USD per flat).
Note: the update of the results of the Pilot object is due to the specific performance of the past heating season in Karaganda (recalculation with the account of actual temperature of the winter period (during the past heating season the decrease in savings is due to a long and cold winter, and deviations from the schedule in heat delivery in the urban system).

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Output 4.2
Prototype and demonstration building designs serve as models for replication, leading to further energy savings and transformation of design/construction practice
Planning, design, and construction of buildings based on energy-efficient designs

baseline.comment: Standard building designs are efficient only to the minimum extent required by code, and do not embody international best practices

target.comment:
Information on prototype building design disseminated to design institutes, regional administrations, development institutions and Agency (Committee) for Construction and Residential-Communal Affairs
Plans, including budgets and initial building designs, established for 20 buildings based on prototypes and demonstration projects

actual.comment:
The UNDP/ GEF Project developed prototype designs of multi-apartment 9- and 5-floor buildings of industrial frame-panel type for non-seismic zones and different climatic zones of the Republic, with application of Energy Efficient engineering solutions. Generic design documentation passed the State Expertise and was approved by the Committee for Construction.
The designed buildings comply with A-class (most efficient) and B-class (high efficiency) of energy efficiency, and also have relatively low budgeted cost of $450-650/m2.
The estimated thermal energy consumption by buildings for the northern climatic areas is 36-82 kWh/(m2*year), while for the southern climatic areas it is 30-65 kWh/(m2*year).
The Committee for Construction sent project design documentation to the regions of the country, where seismic conditions allow possible construction of such objects (the western, northern and central regions of Kazakhstan).
In order to implement the designs, production of precast concrete units as per stock list and drawings, which were developed within the designs, is planned on the basis of the house building factories which are being built in regions of the country.
Additionally, UNDP/GEF project sent project design documentation to stakeholders, such as “Real Estate Fund “Samruk-Kazyna”, private company “KKiK”, “Zhilstroysberbank” and others. UNDP / GEF Project, together with the Committee for construction carried out activities to announce EE projects in 8 cities of Kazakhstan with the total number of more than 800 participants. A letter of interest was received to promote prepared projects of the energy efficient typical houses from "Samruk-Kazyna Real Estate Fund" and from a private investor from Atyrau. Work carried out by UNDP / GEF project to disseminate information about the prepared projects for the energy efficient typical houses in 2015-2017, will allow building more than 30 likewise objects.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
Output 4.3
Cost analysis establishes basis for correcting the maximal cost per one m2 of construction
Reassessment and revision of ceiling cost per m2 of new housing by construction of energy efficient buildings being funded by the government

baseline.comment: Existing ceiling cost per one m2 of new government-funded housing is about $400. There are no exceptions. It is difficult or impossible to design EE buildings under this cost ceiling

target.comment:
Formal recommendations on raising cost ceiling per one m2 of new government-funded housing submitted to Agency for Construction and Residential-Communal Affairs and regional administrations
Cost ceiling per one m2 of new government-funded housing raised, what is a major mechanism for government financing of energy-efficient residential construction

actual.comment:
1) Based on implemented pilot building experience in Karaganda City, the Government adopted some measures on energy efficiency improvement of new construction. In 2014 by the Government Decree amendments and addendums were made to the Affordable Housing Program and construction cost was increased in regions (except for Astana and Almaty Cities) for social housing by 5-10% on average, i.e. from $ 495/m2 to $550/m2.
2) With the adoption of the new economic policy "Nurly Zhol" at the end of 2014 in Kazakhstan approaches to the construction of housing for government programs were revised. In particular, construction plans for rental housing were expanded (with and without compensation), the cost of which will be from 800 to 1000 USD per square meter. This greatly expands the possibilities for the application of energy efficient technologies and materials in the mass housing construction of economic and social class of comfort.
3) With the support of UNDP / GEF project for the first time in Kazakhstan a methodology to estimate the cost of life cycle of the building was used (to evaluate the benefits of investing in energy-efficient measures by assessing the recurrent costs during the operation of the building). Calculations showed that with 9.5% rise in price of construction of the pilot house (on EE activities) savings on recurrent costs of the life cycle of the house is about 47%. Details of these calculations can be used to make decisions about the construction of such EE buildings and will be used in the final recommendations of the UNDP / GEF project.

location.name: Almaty
location.description: seat of a first-order administrative division

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Tonnes of CO2 emissions reductions resulting from transport modal switches to public transport services 2. Number of firm commitments from stakeholders for the implementation of improved public transport services in the City of Almaty 3. Number of financing institutions committed to financing SUT 4. Percent increase in public transit ridership

baseline.comment: 1. Kazakhstan is the largest GHG emitter in Central Asia with annual emissions of 243 MtCO2e . 2. The transport sector is its fastest growing source of CO2 emissions projected to increase from 9 MtCO2/yr in 2008 up to 22 MtCO2/yr in 2012 and 36 MtCO2/yr in 2020 . 3. A significant share of transport emissions is associated with ground transportation in the former capital city of Almaty, the largest and most densely populated city in the country with a population of 1.6 million . Its population is expected to exceed the 2 million threshold in the next 3 to 5 years. 4. Using the annual growth factor of 18% for motor vehicles in Almaty from 2003 to 2008, a business-as-usual (BAU) approach to urban transport in Almaty will result in a steady increase in CO2 emissions of 16.8 million tonnes by 2015 and 24.0 million tonnes by 2020. 5. The main sources of GHG emissions from Almaty motor vehicles have been and will consist of the products of combustion from gasoline and diesel fuels. The viable alternative to private cars should be public transport. Unfortunately, Almaty’s public transport has evolved into a system that does not provide for comfort, convenience and efficient services to commuting passengers. Almaty has an extensive surface passenger transport system comprised of autobus, trolleybus and tram routes. The system, however, is poorly regulated delivering urban transport services that cannot compete with the private car for efficiency and comfort. With a lack of technical, managerial and fiscal capacity to deliver safe reliable public urban transport, there is a wide variance of service quality and a low public perception of the system.

target.comment: 1. Optimization of public transport routes initiated 2. BRT corridor identified, BRT study tours and related training conducted 3. International conference on Transport oriented development organized, knowledge sharing workshops conducted 4 Training's for the Almatyelectrotrans/Transport Holding staff organized to improve quality of services and PT monitoring capacity/transport modeling 5 Social advertisement campaign organized and new web site for passenger created 6 Bike line pilot project identified and design phase implemented 7 Technical assistance for preparation of Concession proposal for LRT provided

actual.comment: 1. Bus routes studies conducted. Draft of the new public transport routes developed and presented to municipality 2. BRT pre-feasibility study completed. BRT 1 corridor identified and approved by municipality. Design phase initiated. BRT study tours for design and operational management staff within municipality organized. Technical assistance for BRT engineering design mobilized 3.International conference organized and got positive feedback from stockholders, resource materials prepared and distributed 4.23 specialists of Almaty Transport Holdings and AET were trained on support monitoring systems and operation of public transportation. 2 person trained in transport modeling and 18 person in PT finance. 5. 300 school posters and leaflets for drivers, explaining the safety rules for riding a bike distributed , social advertisement campaign successfully conducted 6. Bike line design (5 km) project approved by municipality and adopted for national standards 7. LRT task force group for management of tender process organized. Financial consultancy services mobilized

target.comment: 1.Optimization of public transport routes developed and submitted for city transport department 2.Technical assistance for BRT feasibility study and design project organized 3.Technical assistance for bike line design project organized 4 Financial consultancy services for LRT project provided 5 Traffic management study initiated 6 New Social advertisement campaign organized and web site for passenger created 7 Training for fare management provided

actual.comment: 1. Proposal and maps of new optimized PT network delivered and presented to Akimat. 2. Team of technical expert provided , workshop for design companies on BRT design organized. Municipality allocated funds for full feasibility study and road design. 3. Design of new Bike line along Timiryazeva street approved and pilot route (1 km) constructed. Audit of all other bike line provided to municipality and public. 4. New work plan for LRT financial consultancy services discussed with stakeholders . Assistance postponed until 2016 5 Traffic management study priorities discussed 6 Social advertisement campaign is in progress. 3 new banners placed at the streets. 7 Training on fare management provided (28 participants incl representatives of some other cities), new tariff system developed and presented to stackeholders

result.title: Objective
result.description: To reduce the growth of GHG emissions from the transport sector in the City of Almaty, Kazakhstan.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Tonnes of CO2 emissions reductions resulting from transport modal switches to public transport services
New version as revised per MTR:
Tonnes of CO2eq emissions reductions resulting from transport modal switches to public transport services/ to nonâ€ motorized transport modes and other project actions.

baseline.comment:
0 ktonnes CO2
New version as reviserd per MTR:
0 ktonnes CO2
Baseline 2011 emission was estimated at 2.654 million tons CO2eq per year
Baseline 2011 emission was estimated at 2.184 million tons CO2eq per year, but subject to be checked by TDM survey

target.comment:
31 ktonnes CO2 eq (direct annual reduction) from starting of demo project commissioning
New version as revised per MTR:
31 ktonnes CO2 (direct annual reduction) from starting of demo project commissioning
308 ktonnes CO2eq (10-year reduction after completion of CAST)
308 ktonnes CO2eq (10-year reduction after completion of CAST)

actual.comment:
LRT line 1 project could generate reduction 540 ktonnes per year.
BRT line 1 - 32,9 ton per year.
Actual direct emissions reduction will be calculated after implementation of the pilots in 2016 (BRT) - 2018 (LRT).

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of firm commitments from stakeholders for the implementation of improved public transport services in the City of Almaty

baseline.comment: No commitments for improving public transport services

target.comment: At least 2 plans for demonstration of improved public transport services in Almaty City by Year 3

actual.comment: Municipality committed to develop LRT 1 and BRT 1 lines and a pilot cycling route. In 2015 Municipality initiated development of new City development plan for 5 years and will use the "City Almaty sustainable transport strategy" as a backbone document.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of financing institutions committed to financing SUT

baseline.comment: No financing institutions committed to financing demo SUT

target.comment: 1 financing institution committed to financing demo SUT by Year 2

actual.comment:
Municipality financed purchasing 200 CNG buses and committed to finance BRT 1 corridor;
EBRD in 2012-2015 financed procurement of 195 trolleybuses and 400 CNG buses, also committed to finance LRT project using PPP scheme.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Percent increase in public transit ridership

baseline.comment:
No increase of passenger trips on public transport
Baseline 2011 subject to be checked by TDM survey

target.comment:
20% increase of passenger trips on public transport by Year 5.
New version as revised per MTR
20% increase of share of sustainable transport modes (10â€year reduction after completion of CAST.
4% increase of share of sustainable transport modes by Year 5 (along CAST pilot corridors

actual.comment: Projected ridership forecast for 2018 was presented in frame of the optimization of public transport network project. Considering optimization, 15% increase of journeys projected for 2018 (9% for buses and trolleybuses). Data will be adjusted after finalizing LRT/BRT feasibility studies and implementation of these pilot projects.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description:
Added as revised by MTR
Number of policy documents on the role of urban mobility on national transport and climate change mitigation policies

baseline.comment:
Added as revised by MTR:
No documents

target.comment:
Added as revised by MTR:
One document presenting how national policies are supporting sustainable mobility in cities around the world by Year 5

actual.comment: Review of energy efficiency policy and recommendations for policy makers were prepared and discussed with stakeholders

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Improved management of public transport and air quality in Almaty City

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Number of streamlined institutional arrangements for developing and regulating urban transport services, and monitoring transport-related GHG emissions and other air pollutants for Almaty
New version as revised per MTR:
Number of streamlined institutional arrangements for developing and regulating urban transport services
Number of streamlined institutional arrangements for monitoring transportâ€related GHG emissions and other air pollutants for Almaty

baseline.comment:
Current institutions unable to advance projects to improve the state of urban transport in Almaty
New version as revised by MTR:
Current institutions unable to advance projects to improve the state of urban transport in Almaty
Current institutions unable to advance projects to improve the state of urban transport in Almaty

target.comment:
One institutional management plan that streamlines arrangements for developing and regulating urban transport services and monitoring transport-related GHG emissions and other air pollutants in Year 1
New version as revised by MTR:
One institutional management plan that streamlines arrangements for developing and regulating urban transport services: Public transport authority set in place in Year 2

actual.comment:
Department of transport analytics and modelling was created under the Transport Authority (Holding). Transport model has been updated based on 2014/2015 studies.
Recommendations aimed improving the GHG inventory coordination system were conducted with governmental agencies.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of standard public service contracts of international standard to be used for private operators delivering public transport services to Almaty

baseline.comment: No effective standard public service contracts for delivery of public urban transport

target.comment: One standard public service contract template for developing improvements in public transit in Almaty is available by Year 1

actual.comment:
Stakeholders discussed a legal basis of introduction of PSC. Introduction of new PSC has been postponed due to delay of introduction of e-ticketing system and corresponding changes in legislation. Stakeholders discussed the subsidies and payment methodology.
Operators were requested to sign new contracts in 2016.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
Number of trained Municipality personnel in monitoring and managing public service contracts for improved urban transport delivery and GEBs
New version as revised by MTR:
Number of trained Municipality personnel in monitoring and managing public service contracts for improved urban transport delivery and monitoring performance of public service contracts GEBs

baseline.comment:
Lack of trained personnel in effective management of public service contracts for public transport services
New version as revised by MTR:
Lack of trained personnel in effective management of public service contracts for public transport services

target.comment:
5 trained personnel in effective management and monitoring of public service contracts for public transport services and GEBs by Year 2
New version as revised by MTR:
5 trained personnel in effective management and monitoring of public service contracts for public transport services and GEB by Year 4

actual.comment: Transport holding staff (23 persons) was trained for effective management and monitoring of public transport.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
Number of M&E systems developed for monitoring performance of public service contracts
New version as revised by MTR:
Number of M&E systems developed

baseline.comment: No M&E system for monitoring performance of public service contracts

target.comment:
M&E system for monitoring performance of public service contracts by Year 2
New version revised by MTR:
1 M&E system for monitoring performance of public service contracts by Year 4

actual.comment: SWOT Analysis of current M&E system was discussed with stakeholders. Introduction of full-integrated M&E system has been postponed until implementation of e-ticketing system (2016) and introduction of new PSC contract

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Number of studies on the true costs and benefits and expected subsidies to sustain public transport quality.

baseline.comment: No understanding of the cost implications to sustain public transport quality

target.comment:
One study on expected subsidies to sustain public transport quality in Almaty City by Year 2
New version as revised by MTR:
One study and expected subsidies to sustain public transport quality in Almaty City by Year 3

actual.comment:
CAST project conducted 2 trainings and presented best international practice to increase capacity of 42 municipality/transport authority staff to discuss and design subsidy policy.
Specific “Fare system” study was proposed to conduct in 2016.
Regulatory changes for subsidies have been analyzed and recommendations have been developed

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Number of monitoring systems for tracking reduction of transport-related GHG and air pollutant emissions

baseline.comment: No monitoring system for tracking GHG or air pollutant emissions from transport in Almaty

target.comment:
1 GHG/air pollutant monitoring system (software, data collection protocols and surveys) to measure and report on CAST direct GHG emission impact by Year 2
New version as revised by MTR:
GHG/air pollutant monitoring system (software, data collection protocols and surveys) to measure and report on CAST direct and indirect GHG emission impact by Year 5

actual.comment:
The municipal department of environmental protection was equipped by the GHG calculation model and methodology of data collection. Local experts were trained on calculation of transport related emissions.
Methodology was introduced to governmental agencies. Recommendations on improvement of monitoring of transport related emissions to improve data collection were developed and presented to governmental agencies.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Number of trained Municipality personnel in operating public transport in an efficient, safe and demand responsive manner.

baseline.comment: Lack of trained personnel in effective daily operation of public transport

target.comment: 5 trained personnel in effective daily management of public transport by Year 2

actual.comment:
Planning and modeling department was created under Transport holding and 3 staff members were trained via CAST and external courses.
48 persons were trained on planning, service quality monitoring and PT finance.
One international conference
focused on issues of different models of realization of electronic ticketing projects, various management models and financing of public transport at the municipal level was conducted.

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: Number of trainees on the operation and maintenance of new public transport rolling stock

baseline.comment: No trained drivers and mechanics on the operation and maintenance of public transport rolling stock

target.comment: 50 trainees on the operation and maintenance of new buses and re-fuelling infrastructure by Year 2

actual.comment:
20 bus technicians were trained on operation and maintenance of CNG buses. To increase sustainability of the training programme, additional 6 teachers and 4 last year students were trained for development of the course on maintenance of CNG transport.
CNG safety guidelines were developed and 1000 copies were distributed among drivers.
Eco-driving course was developed and transferred to 31 local instructors for further implementation

indicator.title: Indicator 9
indicator.description:
Added as revised by MTR:
Number of institutional arrangements for coordinating sustainable mobility policies within the Municipality based on SUTS

baseline.comment:
Added as revised by MTR:
Fragmentation of competences and actions within the Municipality.

target.comment:
Added as revised by MTR:
One formal Working Group on Sustainable Mobility established within the Municipality, including coordination with urban planning by Year 3

actual.comment: Development of Formal Task Force group on transport projects was established within the Municipality, including coordination with urban planning project.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Improved efficiency and quality of public transport services

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: An optimized public transit route network developed by a transport-demand model

baseline.comment: City public transport network that has poor connections and routings and is not an integrated system.

target.comment:
An optimized integrated public transport route network that has been developed by a new Transport Demand Model by Year 2
New version as revised by MTR:
An optimized public transit route network that has been developed by a new transportâ€ demand model by Year 4

actual.comment:
The Transport demand model (TDM) was designed in order to be capable to forecast travel demand and future performances of highway and public transportation network for years under various scenarios.
Daily ridership study for suburb areas and network optimization report were conducted and delivered to municipality. New hierarchy was proposed and adjusted via TDM. Some routes have already been optimized (11 re-organized, 4 cancelled)

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: A holistic and integrated Sustainable Urban Transport Strategy and Action Plan

baseline.comment: Lack of holistic and integrated planning of Sustainable Urban Transport

target.comment: One integrated Sustainable Urban Transport Strategy and Action Plan approved by Municipality by end of Year 2

actual.comment: The Sustainable urban transport strategy 2013-2023 document and the Action plan were developed and presented to Municipality. The strategy promotes a much more integrated approach, linking all modes of transport together and coordinating them with city development. This will require close collaboration between all partners. This strategy sets new key directions, policy targets and plans for the city. More than 20 organizations took part in discussions of the policies and related indicators through the experts and stakeholders meetings. Key indicators and policies developed under the strategy were recommended to utilize in frame of development of new City master plan (2015-2035) and transferred for introduction in the City Almaty action plan (2016-2020) developed by municipality.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of training programs, local conferences and workshops, field visits on Sustainable Transport

baseline.comment: Lack of knowledge on sustainable transport policies, strategies and projects

target.comment:
1 program to enhance knowledge and skills within the Municipality on Sustainable Transport based on international best practice examples by Year 2
New version as revised per MTR:
At least two conferences and two workshops on international best practice examples organized by Year 4

actual.comment:
2 international knowledge sharing conferences (115 participants) and 3 study tours, series of public open lectures were conducted to increase knowledge of policy makers, NGOs and scientific institutions about sustainable mobility policies and practices. Series of meetings with international experts were organized for local stakeholders. 115 representatives of Akimat and scientific institutions were trained regarding modern instruments of transport planning.
15 representatives of key partners enhanced knowledge through participation at international conferences on development of green transportation outside of Kazakhstan.
Representatives of 6 departments of Akimat and other stakeholders were involved in discussion of the strategy document.
Consultations on development of sustainable urban transport projects at local level were delivered to universities and
to Eco-forum. Based on materials submitted by experts and coordination with the Ministry of Transport of the Republic of Kazakhstan, the Green transport policy concept was presented as one of a chapter and included in the Green Economy Concept adopted by President of Kazakhstan.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of feasibility studies for the development of sustainable transport improvements that include LRT, BRT and feeder routes, parking, cycling and pedestrian areas

baseline.comment: Piecemeal initiatives for the development of sustainable transport in Almaty

target.comment: At least 1 feasibility study on developing sustainable transport improvements in Almaty by Year 2

actual.comment:
Feasibility study for the Light Rail Tram (LRT) project in Almaty has been developed by Municipality and will be used for development of PPP LRT tender. This study was based on the data and studies collected by the project.
BRT pre-feasibility study justifies the main BRT corridors and proposes the first BRT line to be developed. Municipality financed preparation of full size feasibility study.
Detailed design of BRT pilot corridor 1 is under development now.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Investment mobilized in less GHG intensive urban transport

baseline.comment: Moderate investments mobilized for less GHG intensive urban transport

target.comment: Commitments for additional financing of less GHG intensive urban transport at the amount of USD 100 million by Year 5.

actual.comment:
USD 74.5 mln EBRD loan for purchasing modern CNG busses
USD 14,2 mln EBRD loan for purchasing of new 195 trolleybuses
USD 47,5 mln Municipal funds spent for purchasing new municipal public transport fleet (additional 200 CNG buses, 17 trams, 200 CNG taxi)

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Number of new rolling stock procured and operated in the public transport system through old bus exchanges

baseline.comment: No program or plans for modernization of public transport rolling stock of the private sector

target.comment: 200 old buses exchanged for new buses in the private sector by Year 3

actual.comment:
600 CNG buses replaced old diesel buses during period 2011-2015.
200 CNG taxi were transferred to the private sector. Commitment of Municipality to procure additional 40 modern articulated buses

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description:
Transferred from Outcome 3 as revised per MTR:
An integrated ticketing system for all public transport modes in Almaty

baseline.comment:
Transferred from Outcome 3 as revised per MTR:
No integrated ticketing system for public transport

target.comment:
Transferred from Outcome 3 as revised per MTR:
1 integrated ticketing system for public transport implemented by Year 4

actual.comment: E-Ticketing system is under procurement via public private partnership cooperation agreement between Transport holding and Municipality. Implementation is scheduled for end of 2015- 2016.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Integrated traffic management

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Number of paid parking schemes for Almaty planned
New version as revised per MTR:
Number of paid parking schemes for Almaty planned and implemented

baseline.comment: No paid parking schemes being planned

target.comment:
2 plans for paid parking schemes in downtown core of Almaty and enforcement of parking restrictions in selected areas of Almaty by Year 2
New version as revised per MTR:
1 plan paid parking schemes in downtown core of Almaty and enforcement of parking restrictions in selected areas of Almaty by Year 4

actual.comment:
International experience in implementation of parking policy was presented to public, municipality and parliamentarian.
The package of documents including the Parking Policy document, the Operational Guidelines and recommendations for amendments to the legislation were developed and transferred to Municipality. Importance of the institutional reform in parking management was highlighted to Mayor.
Institutional changes and reorganization of the municipal parking company as a sustainable basis for development of pilots are under discussion. Some legislation changes for enforcement of paid parking have been approved.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of traffic management schemes planned

baseline.comment: Ad hoc measures taken to improve traffic flows in Almaty

target.comment:
2 traffic management schemes by Year 3
New version as revised per MTR:
One traffic management schemes developed by Year 4

actual.comment: Concept of implementation of new traffic management scheme discussed with Municipality. Development postponed until finalizing of the City Master plan in 2016. Municipality requested to allocate co-finance for road traffic data collection before initiation of traffic management scheme proposal.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
An integrated ticketing system for all public transport modes in Almaty
As revised per MTR, this indicator was transferred to Outcome 2

baseline.comment:
No integrated ticketing system for public transport
As revised per MTR, this indicator was transferred to Outcome 2

target.comment:
1 integrated ticketing system for public transport implemented by Year 3
As revised per MTR, this indicator was transferred to Outcome 2

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of plans for restricting motor vehicle movements along certain corridors to encourage pedestrian and cycling (non-motorized vehicle traffic) and retail economic development

baseline.comment:
No plans for pedestrians or cycling corridors
Added as revised per MTR:
No plans for traffic calming

target.comment:
1 plan for restricting motor vehicle movement along a selected corridor to encourage pedestrian and cycling corridors and enhance retail economic development by Year 3
Added as revised per MTR:
1 plan for new pedestrian and traffic calming areas by Year 4

actual.comment:
Proposals for extension of cycling corridors for city center were developed and transferred to municipality
20 representatives of design companies, state construction expertise agency and public organizations obtained new knowledge about cycling inclusive infrastructure design. The bike safety school and printing of several posters were supported in order to train young cyclists, reduce traffic accidents and promote safe driving. Development of conceptual design of city center reconstruction was taken into account with commitment of Municipality to create pedestrian and traffic calming zones.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Number of official quality taxi and taxi-stands available to the public.

baseline.comment: Taxi sector does not offer an attractive alternative

target.comment: 1 study on improved quality of taxi sector by Year 1

actual.comment: N/a

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Demonstration projects on sustainable transport

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Bankable engineering plans for demonstration SUT project in Almaty City

baseline.comment: No demonstration projects on sustainable transport

target.comment: At least 1 demonstration on sustainable transport in Almaty. Selection of demonstration project by Year 2. Preparation by Year 3. Implementation Year 4. Operational by Year 5.

actual.comment:
LRT 1 (22 km) feasibility study was developed and approved by Municipality.
Technical assistance for development of the tender documentation for LRT project via public private partnership (PPP) scheme was provided.
Detailed feasibility study of BRT corridor 1 and detailed design of
BRT 1 line (21 km) are under detailed design phase now.
Design of a new bike line (5 km) was finalized and presented to municipality.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of financing institutions that commit financing assistance to demonstration SUT

baseline.comment: No financing institutions committed to financing demonstration SUT

target.comment: 1 financing institutions committed to financing demo SUT by Year 2

actual.comment:
LRT project was considered for financing via public private partnership (PPP) scheme. Tender documentation is under development.
Akimat committed to finance BRT 1 project.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of corridors with separated bus lanes and LRT in operation

baseline.comment: 0 km of operational bus lanes and LRT

target.comment: Two corridors with separated bus lanes and one corridor of LRT in operation by Year 5

actual.comment: Corridors for LRT and BRT lines were identified and included to the new city master plan. Two separated bus lanes were organized by municipality in 2015

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of corridors of improved trolley bus routes in operation

baseline.comment: 0 corridors of improved trolley bus routes in operation

target.comment: One improved corridors trolley service by Year 5

actual.comment: Municipality using EBRD loan purchased new 195 trolleybuses. Trolleybus depot was re-constructed. New management scheme and route optimization to improve efficiency of operation were recommended to Almatyelectrotrance. Recommendations for creation of additional workplaces for women were discussed with EBRD/Almatyelectrotrance

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Percent increase in public transport ridership

baseline.comment: 0% increase on public transport ridership Baseline 2012 will be set by the TDM surveys and monitored annually afterwards. A monitoring plan to be implemented in Year2.

target.comment: 20% increase in public transport ridership by Year 5.

actual.comment: N/A

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Number of actions to promote public awareness on sustainable transport and CAST project

baseline.comment: No public awareness of Sustainable Transport and CAST project

target.comment: 1 public web-site and two promo materials about sustainable transport and CAST project designed by Year 1 at least 30% of citizen of Almaty aware about sustainable transport principles by end of Year 3

actual.comment:
Project continued distributing information about sustainable transport and green mobility principals through mass media and organized 7 thematic workshops in Almaty.
3 information booklets, 2 thematic publications, 2 translated technical guidelines, 2 posters and more than 30 presentations about CAST project objectives and pilots were distributed in frame of 5 international conferences in Almaty, 8 presentations were presented at conferences outside of Kazakhstan and in frame of 4 workshops in Astana.
Tree types of social advertisement were demonstrated in buses along main transport corridors.
Tree cartoons and two social videos to promote green public transport and cycling safety were developed and distributed broadly.
Communication with public was organized through regularly updated project web page and pages in social networks (Facebook, Twitter, and Vkontakte). Based on media monitoring and reports about distribution of social advertisement at the streets and in the network, project estimated that about 30% of citizen of Almaty (0,5 mln) have been informed about key sustainable transport principles.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Number of urban transport information centres established

baseline.comment: 0 information centres established

target.comment: 1 information centre on SUT demo project established in Year 3

actual.comment: Public awareness campaign is under implementation. Leaflets, posters and video materials posted at the billboards and distributed via social networks and available for at least 30 %of citizens of Almaty. New map of the city public transportation network has been elaborated and passed to the city municipality. It will help to improve attractiveness of public transport and provide good quality navigation service for passengers.

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: Number of websites related to improved public transport in Almaty

baseline.comment: 0 websites on public transport

target.comment: 1 website related to improved public transport in Almaty by Year 3

actual.comment: A new public web site for Transport holding is under development. It will include public feedback/complain module/CAST project web page with a library.

indicator.title: Indicator 9
indicator.description: Number of workshops where experience of demonstration projects is shared

baseline.comment: 0 workshops conducted

target.comment: 3 workshops where experience of demonstration projects is shared completed by Year 5

actual.comment: No progress

indicator.title: Indicator 10
indicator.description: Number of papers documenting performance of demonstration projects at reducing transport-related GHG emissions

baseline.comment: 0 papers that document demo project performance

target.comment: 5 papers documenting performance of demonstration projects at reducing transport-related GHG emissions by Year 5

actual.comment: No progress

indicator.title: Indicator 11
indicator.description: Number of plans for replicating demonstration projects

baseline.comment: 0 plans for replicating demo projects

target.comment: 2 plans for replicating demonstration projects by Year 5

actual.comment: BRT/bike line projects were discussed with administrations of Astana/Bishkek cities. Information about Almaty pilots was shared in frame of Covenant of Mayors Forum and other international events.

indicator.title: Indicator 13
indicator.description:
Added as revised per MTR:
Number of one street parking places removed or regulated under

baseline.comment:
Added as revised per MTR:
Ineffective regulation

target.comment:
Added as revised per MTR:
500 parking places removed or regulated in connection with new PT corridors and NMT schemes

actual.comment: Potential for removing/regulation of on -street parking places discussed in frame of BRT pre-feasibility study. Exact numbers will be identified during detailed design phase.

indicator.title: Indicator 14
indicator.description:
Added as revised per MTR:
Number of plans for improving NMT implemented

baseline.comment:
Added as revised per MTR:
No plans implemented

target.comment:
Added as revised per MTR:
One new pedestrian and cycling corridor implemented by Year 5.
One plan for expansion traffic calming zones implemented by Year 5

actual.comment: One corridor (5 km) for improvement of cycling infrastructure is under design phase. New potential corridors were identified; proposals for further development were submitted to municipality. Based on proposals for improvement of pedestrian infrastructure, local municipalities developed several corresponding proposals.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: -Piloting of innovative system of providing special social services to the elderly at home, development of a network of day centres for elderly, centres for social adaptation for the homeless -More than 22,000 oralmans in the territory of EKO receive adaptation services in the Centre for Adaptation and Social Integration in Semei city -Over 500 micro and macro enterprises (with more than 3000 people) benefit from the development of entrepreneurial skill and knowledge on climate change adaptation in 17 districts of EKO

baseline.comment: Vulnerable groups, especially women, children, migrants, refugees, young and aged people, people with disabilities need improved access to markets, goods, services and social safety nets.

target.comment: 1. Improving access to social and economic services through training of social workers of Public Health System, the employees of cultural centers and internal affairs bodies on basics of sign language. 2. Training of persons with impaired visual function on classical wellness massage. 3. Support of vocational - technical education for repatriates. 4. Business services at the rayon level, provided by online centers with participation of Focal points. 5. Business Support Grant Program.

actual.comment: with the financial support of UNDP the following trainings were organized: 15 social workers of the health system (training medical, psychological, educational, legal, household skills and skills of occupational therapy) and 15 public officials (PSC, museums, specialized libraries) have learned sign language to improve the efficiency of service of the population with limited hearing; 2. 15 persons with severe visual functions learned classical wellness massage, including those with the first group of disability. 3. Repatriates continue to be one of the most vulnerable groups in the region. In order to improve their professionalism and competitiveness, the UNDP organized short-term vocational training courses. Fields of study were identified based on the results of the specially conducted survey in 2013. 4. In 2014 on the basis of online centers 95,842 people have been trained and consulted, including 66,535 rural entrepreneurs, unemployed people, civil servants and PWD. 5.In order to support the business in June 2014 the second phase of the grant programme was held to support "Green Business" SMEs implemented by PF "Development of Youth Entrepreneurship" (hereinafter - "OFRMP"). The second meeting of the Grant Committee was held in November. A budget of $ 33,000 enabled to launch 8 selected business projects, three of which have been co-financed under the state program "Roadmap employment 2020", and the remaining 5 were financed in the framework of the Joint Programme and with the contribution of PF "Development of Youth Entrepreneurship".

target.comment: 1. Grant program for inclusive projects (creation of a "barrier-free environment", employment promotion, social support facilities, capacity building of NGOs and individuals working in the social sphere). 2. Courses for repatriates (computer literacy and language. 3. Business Support Grant Program. 4. Monitoring of projects.
