result.title: Objective
result.description: To phase out inefficient lighting and transform lighting markets towards greater energy efficiency, while ensuring product quality and cost-effectiveness, as well as safe disposition of spent mercury-containing lamps.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Electricity consumption and associated GHG emissions from lighting

baseline.comment: 10.0 TWh/year and 9.3 million tons of CO2/year

target.comment: 7 TWh/year and 6.5 million tonnes of CO2/year.

actual.comment: 7.6 TWh/year and 7.4 million tonnes of CO2/year.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Adoption of IL phase-out and associated policies

baseline.comment: IL phase-out adopted but without specific implementation plans

target.comment: IL phase-out and full range of accompanying policies implemented, including technical standards

actual.comment:
By the “Energy saving and energy efficiency” Law dated January 13, 2012 the incandescent lamps are subject for a gradual withdrawal.
The Law includes a few phases of realization:
The first phase: since July 1, 2012 100 Wt and higher incandescent lamps are to be withdrawn from the import and production.
The second phase ????: since January 1, 2013 – 75Wt and higher.
The third phase: since January 1, 2014 ???? - 25 Wt and higher.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Share of incandescent lamps, CFLs, and other types of conventional and efficient lighting

baseline.comment: Share of IL lighting accounts for 77 percent of total lighting in buildings. Lamps up to 100W are permitted to use till July 2012.

target.comment: Incandescent lighting is no longer sold for conventional applications in Kazakhstan. In addition to medium-term targets the documented enlargement of LED share on market is 6 % from the total lighting in the country.

actual.comment:
Incandescent lamps cover 32% of all lighting in buildings.
Incandescent lamps are banned for sale in Kazakhstan.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Quantity of contained and uncontained mercury from lamps, relative to the overall quantity of Hg-containing lamps in the market. This indicator depends directly on Hg content of lamps, their operating lifetime, and effectiveness of collection and containment.

baseline.comment:
No limit on quantity of mercury in CFLs.
No requirement or standards for operating life time of CFLs
Containment not defined quantitatively; collection and recycling only from state agencies and larger enterprises, not general public

target.comment: At least three regional programs for collection and containment of spent fluorescent lamps, with documented 50 percent recovery of mercury from spent lamps.

actual.comment:
The number of the collected and utilized lamps is 6,57 mln lamps (2,47 mln for the reported period)
In Astana the utilization of mercury lamps from local population continues. 1200 thous. lamps have been collected.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Mobilization of investment and other financial support for EE lighting in Kazakhstan

baseline.comment: Investment and state budget support for EE lighting is just beginning in Kazakhstan

target.comment: US $28 million in co-financing for EE lighting secured and applied

actual.comment: 11 mln U.S. dollars were spent from the local budgets for the EE lighting for the period of 2014

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Policy development and implementation supports effective IL phase-out, expansion of market share and use of EE lighting, and safe disposition of spent Hg-containing spent lamps

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Requirements of technical standards for EE lighting

baseline.comment: No technical standards for EE lighting

target.comment: Technical standards developed, adopted, and enforced for EE lighting

actual.comment: 7 technical standards for EE lighting were developed and approved

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Code requirements for energy performance of lighting in buildings

baseline.comment: Minimum 55 lumens per watt (for limited applications)

target.comment: Additional revision of SNRK 2.04-05-2002 and others for greater energy efficiency, including recommendatory sections

actual.comment: 55 lumen minimum per 1 Watt (for limited light sources). There were worked out recommendations for the Committee of construction and housing services of the Ministry for Regional Development of the RK and other relevant organizations according to new requirements and/or reference sections in lighting norms and/or other normative documents.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Procurement of energy-efficient lighting by public agencies

baseline.comment: Public agencies do not consider life-cycle costs or energy efficiency of lighting equipment in procurement

target.comment: Observance of recommended procurement guidelines by at least two national agencies or other bulk purchasers.

actual.comment: In accordance with the order ?415 dated March 31, 2015 the state purchases shall be performed in accordance with the new approved requirements to lighting fixtures for indoor and outdoor lighting.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: State policy and program on mercury (Hg) containment and recovery

baseline.comment: National mandate for Hg containment and recovery developed by RK Ministry of Environmental Protection and sent to regional governments. No regional programs yet implemented in response. No organized collection of spent lamps among general public.

target.comment: Processes for collection of mercury wastes operating nationwide. At least three regional programs for collection of mercury wastes, with documented 50 percent recovery of mercury from spent lamps.

actual.comment:
The number of the collected and utilized lamps is 6,57 mln lamps (2,47 mln for the reported period)
In Astana the utilization of mercury lamps from local population continues. 1,2 mln lamps have been collected.
Since March, 2015 the Program for mercury lamps utilization started in Mangistau oblast.

target.comment: Regulatory documents developed

actual.comment:
Manual for electrical lighting and energy efficiency was developed and approved for the higher educational institutions.
Based on the research which analyzed the possibility to introduce ESCO in the lighting sector of the RK there were made amendments and additions into the “Amendments and additions in energy efficiency issues” Law of the RK ?279-V dated January 14, 2015.
There were determined requirement for testing labs at the state level, there was defined the list of the basic equipment for testing labs for the tasks of certification and verification of the lighting production.
The Law of the Minister for Investments and Development of the RK ?415 dated March 31, 2015 (valid as a decree of the RK) has approved the following:
- requirements to minimal light efficiency of LED lamps
- new requirements to the lighting fixtures of indoor lighting in public and administrative buildings
- new requirements to lighting fixtures for lighting the housing objects
- new requirements to lighting fixtures for street lighting

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Implementation of incandescent-lighting phase-out

baseline.comment: Phase-out included in adopted RK law On Energy Efficiency, but without specific implementation plans.

target.comment: Phase-out implemented in stages and documented (100W bulbs phased out by 2013, 75W bulbs by 2014, and 25W bulbs by 2015).

actual.comment:
By the “Energy saving and energy efficiency” Law dated January 13, 2012 the incandescent lamps are subject for a gradual withdrawal.
The Law includes a few phases of realization:
The first phase: since July 1, 2012 100 Wt and higher incandescent lamps are to be withdrawn from the import and production.
The second phase ????: since January 1, 2013 – 75Wt and higher.
The third phase: since January 1, 2014 ???? - 25 Wt and higher.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Increased accessibility and market share of EE lighting

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Market share of incandescent lamps, CFLs, and other types of conventional and efficient lighting

baseline.comment:
Incandescent lighting accounts for 77 percent of all lighting in buildings. Lamps up to 100W permitted as of July 2012
Light-emitting diodes (LEDs) account for 3 percent of the market for light sources in Kazakhstan

target.comment:
Incandescent lighting is no longer sold for conventional applications in Kazakhstan
LEDs are available for indoor and outdoor applications nationwide and account for 6 percent total national market share for lighting.

actual.comment:
Incandescent lamps cover 32% of all the lighting in buildings.
LEDs account for 28 percent of the market for light sources
There were analyzed production quantities of lamps by types and lighting units within the period 2012 – 2014.
Lighting market research by usage of lamps and lighting fixtures (established pool) in major scopes of application;
Analysis of foreign-economic activity by quantities of import/export of lighting technologies (quantities in number and price aspects with characteristics of products and its basic prices) for the period of 2012-2014.
Evaluation of the capacity of Kazakhstan lamps market for the period of 2012 – 2014.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Increased familiarity among diverse stakeholders with EE lighting and associated issues

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Awareness of general public about advantages of EE lighting, rating and labeling systems for lighting, and proper handling of spent mercury-containing lamps, as measured by quantitative scoring of survey data
Coverage of outreach campaigns, in terms of population

baseline.comment: Not defined quantitatively. General public widely disregards advantages of EE lighting. Rating/labeling systems and mercury-lamp collection programs for general public do not exist.

target.comment:
Outreach campaigns conducted, reaching 6.5 million citizens.
Forty percent of overall population is aware of advantages of EE lighting, rating and labelling systems for lighting, and proper handling of spent mercury-containing lamps

actual.comment:
The project has totally 5 videos. 2013 – 2 videos made, one video promotes mercury utilization, and another video shows advantages of energy efficient lighting. These videos were actively promoted in 2014. The utilization video was rotated in the cinemas of «Kinopark» label, afterwards Astana municipality helped to show this video on TV. Currently the video is shown in Astana public places, such as railway stations, buses, center for people services, etc. The video is posted on youtube, also it is shown during project events. In the period of 2013-2014 when it was actively promoted it covered about 600 thous.people. In 2014-2015 it covered about 200 thous. people. Up to date it totally covered 800 thous.people.
The extended video about various advantages of energy efficient lighting was submitted to the MINT (now Ministry for investment and development) which helped to have it shown on state channels. Currently it is promoted during project events. 2013-1014 – the video covered 600 thous.people; 2014-2015 – 100 thous.people, totally – 700 thous.people covered.
Two videos made, 3D video and a cartoon. The cartoon shows the lighting evolution, and the 3D video talks about energy saving and EE lighting. The videos are promoted on the internet. Also there were made EE lighting awareness installations which then were distributed among project partners. The Project Facebook page is regularly updated and has a growing number of followers and viewers The Project always participated in contests related to energy saving ideas promotion. Totally printed materials distribution covered about 10 thous.people:
2012-2013 – 1 thous. people. 2013-2014 – 7 thous people. 2014-2015 – 2 thous.people.
In 2014 there were made PR events in various cities of Kazakhstan in the form of installing informational stands in city squares, during those events people were informed about EE lighting and were given project printed materials. The events took place in Astana, Almaty, Atyrau, and Aktau in August-September, 2014.
Six press-briefings were given in Astana, Atyrau, Aktau, and Semey in the period of June-November, 2014.
The project regularly conducts media-trainings for journalists regarding use of multi-media tools when discussing issues of energy efficiency. In 2014 media-trainings were made in Ust-Kamenogorsk, Kyzylorda, and Aktau. In 2015 in Eastern and Southern Kazakhstan two media-trainings were carried out. In 2015 media-trainings were given in Kyzyorda, Shymkent, and Aktau.
TV shows: In 2015 in three regions of the country (Aktau, Shymkent, Kyzylorda) the project experts participated in the TV talk-shows to discuss energy saving and energy efficiency.
Totally seminars, media-trainings, and TV shows covered about 400 thous.people, 2013-2014 – 250 thous.people, 2014-2015 – 150 thous.people.
Trainings were given to trainers of energy auditors according to study module for energy audit of lighting systems in buildings, structures, and street lighting. The project participated in the training seminars for energy managers in Energy Efficiency Centers (about 500 people covered). 2013-2014 – 350 people. 2014-2015 – 150 people.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Increased investor confidence, design and administrative capacity, and market share of EE lighting as a result of demonstration projects

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Energy savings and GHG emissions reductions from EE upgrades of lighting in selected public buildings or street-lighting projects

baseline.comment: Outdated lighting technology is widely used in both buildings and street lighting. Quantitative baseline parameters to be determined during design phase for each specific project.

target.comment:
31,000 tons of direct avoided CO2 emissions over operating lifetime of deployed demonstration technology.
Specific technical and economic performance targets to be determined for each project.

actual.comment:
Project had modernized street lighting systems in 5 pilot areas within Kazakhstan: Northern, Eastern, Western, and Central regions. Energy efficient LED lighting equipment with automatic control was installed. Power saving is 5 961 MWt/h which shall prevent from 5550 CO2 emission from fuel combustion used for power generation.
Together with the Project and the new Joint Program of the UN and Mangistau and Kyzylorda oblasts the lighting was modernized in schools. Demonstration projects include lighting modernization of the 41 classrooms in 4 schools of Kyzylorda and Mangistau.
Powert saving is 2 976 MWt/h which shall prevent from 2 775 ??2 emission from fuel combustion used for power generation.
Total GHG emissions reduction amounted to 10 850 tons ??2

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Replication of demonstration project results, in terms of number of projects, number of regions, and amount of financing mobilized

baseline.comment: Business-as-usual does not reflect practices that are to be applied in demonstration projects

target.comment:
Replication of demonstration project results in at least five projects in five regions
At least $12 million invested in EE lighting projects

actual.comment:
Funds were assigned from the local budget in:
Eastern-Kazakhstan oblast: 420 modern LED lighting fixtures were installed in Ust-Kamenogorsk for the roadway lighting. In 2014 all over Eastern-Kazakhstan oblast 13 884 energy saving lighting fixtures were installed for the amount of 4,1 mln dollars.
In Pavlodar oblast among 30 250 street lighting fixtures more than 11 thousand or 35% were changed to energy saving types for the amount of 3,3 mln dollars. Also 28 sets of automated street lighting were installed for the total amount of 23 000 dollars.
In Northern-Kazakhstan oblast there was installed and set the automated system for street lighting control through the GSM network covering 40% of the capacity. 400Wt mercury lighting fixtures were completely replaced with the 250 Wt energy saving types. The economic saving for a year was 20 000 dollars. In oblast 55% of all the street and park lighting was replaced with the energy saving lamps.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Outcome 1. Update of the National Implementation Plan (NIP) on Stockholm Convention is prepared and coordination on chemical MEAs is enhanced. Outcome 2. Mercury inventory and Reduction plan prepared. Mercury waste generated by the health sector is managed soundly. Outcome 3. POPs emissions from healthcare waste incineration are reduced through a replacement of installations on HCW incineration by alternative in the selected regions.

baseline.comment: - No inventory on new POPs. - NIP not updated. - Routine waste incineration without emission controls and risk reduction measures is commonly practiced. - Low level of practical knowledge and use of non-combustion techniques. - Baseline emissions constitute 124.88 g TEQ/a to air, and 0.65 g TEQ/a to bottom ash. - No training on new POPs is currently planned on POPs issue in Kazakhstan. - Limited information on new POPs is available. - Original 2003-2005 uPOPs inventory conducted with a limited set of industrial sources and outdated. - No full range of POPs and POPs in goods/environment is handled by existing laboratories. - No POPs coordination center. - Ecological Code contains only general information on POPs management (chapter 40 on dangerous chemicals), with amendments related to PCBs. - No national training held on new POPs. - No previous larger scale efforts applied to build capacity of related stakeholders on mercury negotiations, mercury convention, mercury associated risks etc. - No national mercury assessment made, except in form of waste product. - No database on sources and mercury releases is in existence. - No full understanding of scale impact on human health.

target.comment: Assessment of the existing legislation on the issues of POPs, healthcare waste and mercury management. Component 1. POPs issues capacity building. Component 2. Conduction of assessment on mercury situation. Component 3. Reduction of uPOPs over healthcare waste treatment. Sound healthcare waste management.

actual.comment: Legislation assessment is conducted, recommendations on amendments are prepared. Component 1. Updated NIP of implementing obligations under Stockholm Convention was prepared; assessment of laboratory capacity for POP monitoring was conducted. Component 2. The main mercury resources identified; assessment of a system of mercury monitoring conducted; campaign on capacity building of mercury management issues conducted as well. Component 3. The pilot sites and hospitals selected; all installations of HCW incineration identified and assessed; sampling of pollutants emissions from installations on HCW incineration of the selected regions conducted; drafts HCWM plans for pilot regions and hospitals prepared.

target.comment: Component 1. To conduct inventory of new and unintentionally POPs. Improvement of legislation system related to issues of POPs, mercury and healthcare waste handling. Component 2. To reduce the volume of produced mercury waste in the selected hospitals. To conduct the assessment of of the situation on mercury releases, prepare recommendations for safe mercury management and Minamata Convention ratification. Component 3. To select the best affordable technologies and testing healthcare waste treatment installations in the selected region, i.e. by the alternative non-incineration methods.

actual.comment:
Component 1: Workshops with the title ‘Outlining national priorities and action plan for the inventory of mercury, persistent organic pollutants, healthcare wastes reduction’ were delivered in pilot regions in order to enhance practical collaboration during inventory of POPs and mercury. With the view to promote the project and create a platform for discussions about efficient wastes management, the project contributed to organization and delivery of the Round Table ‘Strategic development of the wastes processing sector in Kazakhstan’ organized within the framework of the 11th Central Asian Specialized Exhibition EcoTech 2015. Inventory of new uPOPs is going on. The following activities were implemented to ensure a synergetic effect of three Conventions: a database with data on implementation of three conventions created; analysis on how provisions of three conventions are implemented in the Republic of Kazakhstan conducted; analysis of best international practices in implementing three conventions conducted; analysis of provisions of three conventions and resolutions of conferences of the parties conducted to set implementation priorities for Kazakhstan. For capacity building in the field of laboratory analysis, control and monitoring of POPs representatives of KazHydroMet and a representative of the laboratory of the Ministry of National economy that analyzes a content of dioxins in food took part in the International Symposium on Persistent Organic Pollutants organized by the International Organization “Dioxin 20XX”. A study tour to Recetox POPs Monitoring Center of the Stockholm Convention Secretariat (Czech Republic) was arranged for employees of governmental and private laboratories to raise their awareness about methods of POPs analysis.
Component 2: Country-wide mercury assessment and initial inventory of possible mercury sources conducted; recommendations on accession to Minamata Convention prepared for the RoK Government; the Concept was included into

result.title: Objective
result.description: To reduce the releases of unintentionally produced POPs and other globally harmful pollutants into the environment by promoting sound healthcare waste management in Kazakhstan, and to assist the country in implementing its relevant obligations under the Stockholm convention.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Update of the National Implementation Plan (NIP) on Stockholm Convention is prepared and coordination on chemical MEAs is enhanced.

baseline.comment:
No inventory on new POPs
Fragmented legislation controls
NIP not updated
Several POPs initiatives are implemented not in a coordinated way

target.comment:
Inventory completed and publicly available
NIP obligations with inclusion of new POPs reviewed and updated.
Updated draft NIP is presented to the Government for review process and endorsement

actual.comment:
Overall, six (6) consultation meetings held at four (4) general workshops on POPs (and in combination with mercury aspects), and two (2) at the premises of Ministry of Energy organized by UNDP during September –November 2014.
An inventory on the use and import of new POPs has been completed, while work on unintentional POPs, and planned work on updated inventory on POPs pesticides are still ongoing. The update on new POPs to NIP was approved by order of the Minister of Energy of the Republic of Kazakhstan 228 dated 30.12.2014 and submitted to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to be presented to the Secretariat for the Stockholm Convention.
National register on POPs establishing their maximum allowed emissions (based on a new decree of the Ministry of Energy – where environmental branch is now attached to – no. 26 dated 25 January 2015) has been created. Previous Resolution of the Government in this respect was outdated and approved in 2007. Current legislative system (after reform) in the country is operated on the basis of branch decrees taken by respective line Ministries, and is regulated overall by the Djasyl Damu (Green Economy) Programme of National Development.
Additionally, amendments on mandatory environmental monitoring of unintentional POPs (dioxins/furans) releases have been proposed to the Ecological Code as part of the Green Economy’s programme amendments.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Mercury inventory and Reduction plan prepared.

baseline.comment:
Stand-alone, site specific mercury contamination remediation programme is in place by the World Bank
No other inventories of mercury initiated and completed and human exposure estimated
No mercury use and release standard set
No national mercury management plan formulated and approved

target.comment:
Mercury situation in Kazakhstan assessed
Inventory is documented
Inter-agency consultations held
National capacity to handle recovered mercury is assessed and recommendations for improvement are set forward Draft National Mercury Reduction Plan developed with identified priorities.
Mercury emission standard established.

actual.comment:
An initial assessment of the existing capacity for the management of mercury has been carried out with support of a selected and sub-contracted national consultancy firm “Centre for Facilitation of Sustainable Development”.
Main sources of mercury pollution have been identified, and a list of companies engaged in recycling and treatment of mercury waste has been prepared. However, the MIA project is able only to provide an overview of the mercury situation, and larger investments will be required in future for full assessment of mercury emitters,
An assessment of the current legislation on mercury handling has been carried out and recommendations for legislative additions/revision have been provided.
The Ministry of Energy in cooperation with local authorities continues to work to remediate a historical mercury hotspot in Pavlodar city (population of 352 693 as of start of 2014), and a WB-supported project in Karaganda was to complete on Nura river contamination.
An inter-agency working group on mercury management, involving Ministries of Foreign Affairs, Industry and Trade, Health, Economy and Social Development, and representatives of industrial associations, was established in January 2015 to support consultations and decision-making on joining the Minamata Convention.
A capacity building program on creating awareness on the risks of the use and release of mercury in the environment; conducting an inventory; identifying sources of mercury emissions; and creating a release database, has been developed.
Four (4) training sessions were delivered on mercury issues (within same series of POPs related regional conferences) as faced by hospitals during the medical waste management: three (3) in October 2014 in Kostanay, Astana, and Ust-Kamenogorsk (250 people), and one (1) larger workshop in September 2014 (50 people).
Justification concept on Minamata convention ratification drafted and is prepared for submission to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs for review.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: POPs emissions from healthcare waste incineration are reduced through a demonstration component, and wider replication of results.

baseline.comment:
Waste segregation for waste source reduction is not a standard accepted approach in medical facilities
Routine waste incineration without emission controls and risk reduction measures is commonly practiced
Low level of practical knowledge and use of non-combustion techniques
Baseline emissions constitute 124.88 g TEQ/a to air, and 0.65 g TEQ/a to bottom ash.

target.comment:
Mid-term:
Releases reduced to 86.08 g TEQ/a to air, and 0.46 g TEQ/a to bottom ash.
End of project:
Releases reduced to 16.38 g TEQ/a to air, and 0.11 g TEQ/a to bottom ash

actual.comment:
Three (3) pilot areas selected for demonstration of alternative non-combustion technologies in treatment of healthcare wastes as a replacement of existing basic incinerators with no installed stack air cleaning systems. These are Kostanay, Astana (capital) and Ust-Kamenogorsk provinces.
An assessment of the waste generation volumes and decontamination of infectious healthcare waste across the country as a whole has been completed. And, in selected pilot areas this assessment has been implemented in all 8 in-patient medical facilities.
For a number of selected incinerators (1 in pilot Kostanay province, and 2 in Ust-Kamenogorsk province, as Astana authorities declined on tests), exemplar stack emission tests were conducted. Dioxin and furan emissions exceeded the EU established maximum allowable concentrations (MACs) on average by 28 times.
Based on technical advice from international expert, the project team had designed Healthcare Waste Management Plans for three selected pilot areas (Kostanay, Astana, and Ust-Kamenogorsk).
These plans include description of currently used healthcare waste management system, proposed alternative ways to improve practices through waste segregation (including the use of needle cutters to reduce accidents at work, and separate out plastic parts for disinfection).
The use of needle cutters to allow for the segregated collection of sharps (metal) and separation of remaining plastic parts of the healthcare waste has been set in the legislation (Decree of Ministry of Health, no. 127 dated 24 February 2015).
Same decree provided for use of alternative methods for healthcare waste treatment.
Four (4) workshops were held, as described in the previous section, to raise awareness of government agencies and medical facilities about alternative ways for healthcare waste treatment (300 people).

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Mercury waste generated by the health sector is managed soundly and future waste is minimized

baseline.comment: Broken thermometers: 236.81 kg/a.

target.comment:
Mid-term:
Releases reduced to (in broken thermometers): 210.81 kg/a.
End of project:
Releases reduced to 200 kg/a

actual.comment: Planned in the next reporting cycle

result.title: Outcome 1.1
result.description: POPs inventories improved for informed decision making and priority setting

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Capacity building programme (trainings) for involved stakeholders developed and implemented on POPs risks, inventories, POPs tracking, monitoring of data reported by responsible parties.

baseline.comment:
Training on PCBs inventory and management is being carried out in the framework of the UNDP PCB project.
No training on new POPs is currently planned on POPs issue in Kazakhstan
Limited information on new POPs is available

actual.comment:
Training program on POPs risks and their sound management has been prepared with help of contracted consultancy firm “Centre for facilitating Sustainable Development”.
This program will be placed on a web-link of consolidated training and awareness resources on sustainable development hosted under the National Development Programme “Djasyl Damu – Green Economy”. In addition, it and other project’s produced materials, will be placed in the Ministry of Energy’s Information and Analytics Centre which is involved in career enhancement education activities for staff members.
Other trainings included the central authority related training, which engaged industrial enterprises, on POPs inventorying which was held in September 2014. This was planned to easy access to date from industrial sector.
During reporting period, the project team together with territorial municipalities and health authorities had selected future project sites – the sites where new alternative technology (non-incineration) will be installed for demonstration purposes. These sites are located in: Kostanay (north-west), Astana (capital, centre-north), and Ust-Kamenogorsk (east) provinces.
Three (3) trainings arranged in these three (3) regions – at selected pilot sites - for 250 people from territorial municipal, health, sanitary and environmental control authorities. Additional main workshop held in September 2014 in Astana for central authorities, and representatives of industry.
Topics of these trainings included risks of POPs, POPs monitoring, institutional roles and responsibilities, legislation for the control of POPs and measures for its implementation.
Measuring training effectiveness is planned for future reporting cycles
Data on new POPs collected and assessed, and formed an update request to the NIP, with follow-up transmission of this information to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and later on to the Stockholm Convention Secretariat.
This has been achieved by statistics and import database searches, requests for information to industrial and private sectors, company visits, etc.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: National information system (inventory) on POPs expanded (updated information on uPOPs and new POPs).

baseline.comment:
·Original 2003-2005 uPOPs inventory conducted with a limited set of industrial sources and outdated.
Inventory of POPs pesticides stockpiles and burial sites limited to 20% of the country at the NIP stage.
Under the sectoral programs “Zhasyl Damu (Green Growth) for 2010-2014”, adopted by the Government of the Republic of Kazakhstan dated September 10, 2010 # 924, a detailed inventory of all POPs and obsolete pesticides is envisaged but not started yet.

target.comment:
uPOPs inventory completed using the most recent data available.
POPs inventories updated for uPOPs and POPs pesticides, covering all the territory of Kazakhstan.
Industrial use of new POPs identified and possible chemical and non-chemical alternatives assessed.
Inventory of stockpiles and burial sites of pesticides covering at least 70% of the country.
Plan for maintaining and completing the above inventories elaborated and institutional responsibilities assigned.
An information system on inventories of POPs substances established

actual.comment:
Preparatory works performed for the determination of the main sources of unintentionally produced POPs, works on further inventory of uPOPs are planned.
Based on open tender, a national consultancy firm “Centre for Facilitation of Sustainable Development” was selected and sub-contracted to support national level activities. Overall, four (4) national experts have been engaged in the process of NIP update. This work was supported by an international expert to guide the process.
Preparatory works have been undertaken to determine the main sources of unintentionally produced POPs; works on further inventory of uPOPs are planned.
Inventory on new POPs has been completed, while work on unintentional POPs, and planned work on updated inventory on POPs pesticides are still ongoing. Data on new POPs have been captured in the NIP update document which was transmitted to the Stockholm Convention secretariat.
NIP update for new POPs was approved by order of the Minister of Energy of the Republic of Kazakhstan 228 dated 30.12.2014 and submitted to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to be presented to the Secretariat for the Stockholm Convention.
Project manager is an invited member to and regularly participates in a decision-making board of the Ministry of Energy on installation of a national hazardous waste disposal plant (HTI – high temperature incineration) in Kazakhstan where future POPs stockpiles can be safely disposed of in line with international best practices.
Information on POPs pesticides in particular will be useful to help Kazakhstan remove these wastes in future when the plant is in operation, and this also provides a feedback mechanism on inventories to the Ministry of Energy.
The main industries that use new POPs have been identified. These sectors include agriculture, engineering, light industry and pharmaceutical industries.
National register on POPs establishing their maximum allowed emissions (based on a new decree of the Ministry of Energy – where environmental branch is now attached to – no. 26 dated 25 January 2015) has been created.

result.title: Outcome 1.2
result.description: National capacities on POPs monitoring, analytical capabilities are assessed

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Studies on existing POPs analytical and monitoring capabilities for the whole range of POPs (with focus on new POPs) carried out

baseline.comment:
A few laboratories identified in the course of NIP preparation and GEF/UNDP PCB management programme.
Laboratories are currently only nationally accredited for PCB analyses
Draft POPs national monitoring plan developed by RECETOX – a Stockholm Convention’s Regional Centre in the Czech Republic.

target.comment:
National POPs monitoring plan approved as part of relevant national policies and documents.
Participation in regional monitoring networks.

actual.comment:
Existing laboratory capacity has been assessed.
About nine (9) laboratories have the potential to determine uPOPs in the various environmental media, provided methodologies are provided and accreditation is supported to enable full commercial activity.
Two (2) laboratories were identified/selected to receive project support for national accreditation.
Maximum allowable emissions for dioxins and furans have been set by Decree of Ministry of Energy # 26 of January 21, 2015.
Further, amendments have been proposed by the project in terms of a law on introducing requirements on POPs monitoring in environment into existing regulatory framework associated with the implementation of the Djasyl Damu (Green Economy) National Development Programme.
A capacity building program on POPs risks, undertaking a POPs inventory and monitoring of POPs has been developed.
This is based on bilateral assistance from UNDP-Czech Trust Fund deployed before in the GEF-UNDP PCB management programme in Kazakhstan. The RECETOX (Brno, Czech Republic based laboratory of regional importance) is a partner selected for this activity. While training will be provided by RECETOX, the project will support travel of 15 laboratory staff.
The following laboratories will participate: Central Sanitary-Epidemiological, KazHydroMeteorological, Central Environmental and private laboratories.
Participation in regional laboratory networks is possible after capacity building part is complete, and national accreditation is in place.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: A set of recommendations for the improvement of such capabilities formulated and submitted to the Government

baseline.comment:
No full range of POPs and POPs in goods/environment is handled by existing laboratories
No national consultations held on priorities
No action plan is in place for improvements

target.comment: At least two (2) laboratories accredited to perform uPOPs analysis in goods/environment;

actual.comment:
Laboratories to be prepared for accreditation are determined.
POPs monitoring activities can only be implemented once appropriate training and capacity building to national laboratories have been delivered, and further supported by additional support in terms of applicable methods and accreditation processes.
A training workshop is planned for laboratories with help from the regional POPs laboratory located in Brno, Czech Republic at premises of the Masaryk University. This laboratory is a designated regional POPs service center (approved by the COP of the Stockholm Convention in 2008) for Europe and Central Asia region.
The Concept of Transition of Kazakhstan to the Green Economy (GE) – Djasyl Damu included general reference to air pollution by dioxins (section 3.6). The Action Plan to implement the Concept of GE included a measure to ensure strengthening of the technical capacity of regional analytical laboratories to obtain reliable operational data on the pollution of surface and groundwater, soil and air in order to undertake rehabilitation and preventive measures, identification and study of pollution areas originating from landfills in order to identify areas in need of cleaning and rehabilitation.

result.title: Outcome 1.3
result.description: Policy, institutional frameworks and enabling regulatory environment are in place to ensure better control on POPs accumulation and emissions

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Institutional coordination and compliance with international agreements improved through firmer institutionalization of POPs issues into national structures

baseline.comment:
No POPs coordination center in existence due to lengthy Government’s approval procedures and unaligned MEP mandate, and mismatch of proposed workplans (to 2028) with 3 year long financial planning processes
POPs coordination happens in a fragmented manner with no alignment of roles
Nu funding sources to sustain POPs coordination function are available

target.comment:
POPs group meets regularly to guide the NIP update process
Institutionalization of new POPs issues into relevant line ministries ensured according to defined roles.
Coordination mechanisms on POPs issues institutionalized and embedded into draft regulations sent for Government’s review and approval
Funding sources to ensure the mechanism’s sustainability are defined, consulted on with MoF, and proposed for inclusion in national planning

actual.comment:
According to the Minutes of the Meeting with the Minister of Energy from 29 June 2015 (# 19-01-01-01/101) the establishment of a working group on POPs management issues is currently planned to become a dedicated group on national POPs management issues.
Project manager is an invited member to and regularly participates in a decision-making board of the Ministry of Energy on installation of a national hazardous waste disposal plant (HTI – high temperature incineration) in Kazakhstan where future POPs stockpiles can be safely disposed of in line with international best practices.
The development of proposals for the institutional structure of public authorities and organizations responsible for the implementation of the three conventions (Basel, Rotterdam and Stockholm) are planned by the project team in consultations with relevant stakeholders.
It is also planned to identify measures to assist the work of the state bodies on the implementation of the three Conventions.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: National legal framework, by aligning institutional roles, reviewed and improved to include the issue of insofar unaddressed POPs, uPOPs and new POPs

baseline.comment:
Ecological Code contains only general information on POPs management (chapter 40 on dangerous chemicals), with amendments related to PCBs supported by GEF/UNDP programme on PCBs
The Government has plans to extend the provisions of chapter 40 to regulate emissions uPOPs
MEP plans measures to improve the operational control of industrial emissions, including burning of fuels, and promote the construction and modernization of facilities for cleaning exhaust gases in the steel industry.

target.comment:
Final report on the improvement of current regulatory system for including the issues of insofar unaddressed POPs, uPOPs and new POPs.
Amended regulation drafted and submitted.

actual.comment:
National register on POPs establishing their maximum allowed emissions (based on a new decree of the Ministry of Energy – where environmental branch is now attached to – no. 26 dated 25 January 2015) has been created. Previous Resolution of the Government in this respect was outdated and approved in 2007.
In addition, maximum allowable concentration of dioxins in the air of populated areas has been defined in sanitary regulations # 168 called "Sanitary-epidemiological requirements to air quality in urban and rural areas, soils and their safety, content areas of urban and rural settlements, conditions of work with sources of physical factors affecting people", adopted by the Government on January 25, 2012.
The current new decree # 26 (Ministry of Energy) sets emission standards for dioxins/furans; however, no monitoring and control system over unintentional POPs exists in the country, except for MACs/emission limits.
Further, amendments have been proposed by the project in terms of a law on introducing requirements on POPs monitoring in environment into existing regulatory framework associated with the implementation of the Djasyl Damu (Green Economy) National Development Programme.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Sectoral technical guidelines updated to include the issue of priority POPs, including sampling and analysis methods

baseline.comment: Guidelines and action plans are being drafted on the sectors related to POPs waste and PCBs, under the UNDP PCB project under Zhasyl Damu (Green Growth) initiative.

target.comment: Technical guidelines and action plans on POPs are submitted for approval by relevant state bodies.

actual.comment: Planned in future reporting cycles.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Capacity building programme (trainings) and consultations for involved stakeholders developed and implemented on POPs related risks, POPs monitoring, institutional roles and responsibilities, POPs control legislation benchmarks and enforcement

baseline.comment:
No national training held on new POPs, developments in the Stockholm Convention and NIP update guidelines;
Currently prevailing insufficient knowledge on new POPs, their risks and control measures and approaches

target.comment:
At least, two (2) complementary workshops held
Sixty (60) stakeholders participated in workshops
Results of stakeholder consultations
NIP update formulated

actual.comment:
Four (4) regional training workshops were conducted on issues related to the management of POPs, including new POPs in three pilot provinces of the country for territorial municipal, health, sanitary and environmental control administrations, including hospitals, as well as for central authorities and industrial associations (300 participants in total).
Overall, six (6) consultation meetings held at the indicated four (4) general workshops, and two (2) at the premises of Ministry of Energy during September –November 2014.
NIP update for new POPs was approved by order of the Minister of Energy of the Republic of Kazakhstan 228 dated 30.12.2014 and submitted to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to be presented to the Secretariat for the Stockholm Convention.
Activity completed.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: National Implementation Plan (NIP) on Stockholm Convention obligations with inclusion of new POPs reviewed and updated, with elaboration of specific action plans on new POPs.

baseline.comment: The Government is carrying out several non-coordinated actions on POPs (update of inventories on pesticidal POPs in 5 regions, PCB management, inventory and partial disposal, planning better control of uPOPs, improving of existing regulations).

target.comment:
Final draft of the NIP completed and circulated for review within the main stakeholders.
Updated NIP submitted for approval to the Government, approved and submitted to the Secretariat.

actual.comment:
During the reporting period, the project team has been working on updating the NIP in regards of the introduction of new POPs. A national contractor firm (of 4 national experts) was selected to organize the data collection and analysis process, based on guidance form international consultant.
Inventory on new POPs has been completed, while work on unintentional POPs, and planned work on updated inventory on POPs pesticides are still ongoing. Data on new POPs have been captured in the NIP update document which was transmitted to the Stockholm Convention secretariat.
The updated National Implementation Plan on new POPs for 2015-2028 was approved by decree of Ministry of Energy # 228 dated 30/12/2014. It was submitted to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to be presented to the Secretariat for the Stockholm Convention.

result.title: Outcome 1.4
result.description: Improved institutional coordination on chemical MEAs

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Review and better alignment of ministerial functions on implementation of Conventions’ obligations

baseline.comment:
No or very fragmented institutional structure overseeing chemicals MEAs
Lack of common knowledge on synergies between chemical MEAs

target.comment:
Roadmap in place for joint coordination of MEAs
Draft regulation to enforce selected recommendations is in place

actual.comment: Planned in future reporting cycles

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Establishment of coordination mechanisms to support synergistic implementation of Stockholm, Rotterdam and Basel Conventions and established framework (system) for monitoring, accountancy and reporting on the implementation of the Stockholm, Basel and Rotterdam conventions in Kazakhstan

baseline.comment:
No conceptual understanding (strategy) on the synergism and collaborative operation of responsible parties
No or very fragmented institutional structure overseeing chemicals MEAs
No formal coordination mechanism established for synergistic implementation of MEAs
No TOR and mandate of the mechanism is in existence
No formal central monitoring on reporting obligations is maintained to assess quality of MEA implementation
Data collection challenges to ensure better reporting

target.comment:
Draft legislation supporting establishment of the coordinating mechanism submitted for review and approval
Temporary (with GEF/UNDP project’s help) and fixed (Government) budgets for operation of the MEA mechanism defined and proposal for financing submitted to MoF
Monitoring system forms part of the prepared draft legislation on the MEA coordinating mechanism
Draft strategic concept and action plan are in place

actual.comment: Planned in future reporting cycles

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
Capacity of government authorities on implementation of chemical conventions improved
Improved data collection and chemical review processes for decision making and control improvements on the import and use of new dangerous chemical substances

baseline.comment:
Lack of legal framework for cooperation among key stakeholders
No previous training on synergies and MEA implementation held
Data collection challenges to ensure better reporting
No conceptual understanding (strategy) on the synergism and collaborative operation of responsible parties
No action plan in place to support operation of the MEA coordinating mechanism

target.comment:
Draft legislation supporting establishment of the coordinating mechanism submitted for review and approval
Received capacity is applied in decision-making forums

result.title: Outcome 2.1
result.description: Mercury assessment implemented, national consultations held to identify priorities for actions and capacity building on mercury risks carried out

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Capacity building programme (trainings) for involved stakeholders developed and implemented on mercury risks, inventories, sources, data tracking

baseline.comment:
No previous larger scale efforts applied to build capacity of related stakeholders on mercury negotiations, mercury convention, mercury associated risks etc
Limitations in the scale of stakeholder activities on mercury, with exception to Ust-Kamenogorsk WB’s programme on decontamination

target.comment: Capacity building program (trainings) for involved stakeholders completed.

actual.comment:
An inter-agency working group on mercury management, involving Ministries of Foreign Affairs, Industry and Trade, Health, Economy and Social Development, and representatives of industrial associations, was established in January 2015 to support consultations and decision-making on joining the Minamata Convention.
Based on a specialized capacity building program which was developed by the project (on mercury risks, inventorying, source profiling, national database), four (4) general workshops were organized during fall time 2014: three (3) in pilot provinces, and one (1) central workshop in the capital city, with 300 people participated, mainly from territorial and central administrations (municipal - Akimats, health, sanitary, environmental), and representatives of industrial associations.
Materials of the assessment of mercury impact on human health conducted by the World Health Organization (www.who.int/ceh) have been used in the preparation of training courses and workshops
The Ministry of Energy in cooperation with local authorities continues to work to remediate a historical mercury hotspot in Pavlodar city (population of 352,693 as of start of 2014), and a WB-supported project in Karaganda was to complete on Nura river contamination.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Mercury situation in Kazakhstan assessed in coordinated manner jointly with UNEP

baseline.comment:
No national mercury assessment made, except in form of waste product
No database on sources and mercury releases is in existence
No full understanding of scale impact on human health

target.comment:
Assessment of country’s mercury sources, releases, contaminated sites and priority areas for mercury control completed
The country’s baseline data is established.
Information made available through database and open access web-site

actual.comment:
Project team announced a call for services and sub-contracted same contractor as for the NIP update – the consultancy firm “Centre for Facilitation of Sustainable Development”.
An initial assessment of the existing capacity for the management of mercury has been carried out.
A basic assessment of the availability of mercury thermometers in inpatient health facilities in the 3 pilot regions was completed through questionnaires in 2013. Data were used in drafting healthcare management plans.
The initial mercury assessment is now underway, and the project will be in position in next reporting cycles to provide an overview of the national situation with Mercury. It is now believed, that due to the size of the country and current experience with parallel ongoing projects on mercury remediation, additional substantial resources will be needed to fully assess mercury emitters once identified.
Based on the initial work, main sources of mercury pollution have been identified, and a list of companies engaged in recycling and treatment of mercury waste has been prepared
Preparatory works for the monitoring of mercury in the environment are performed in cooperation with the uPOPs monitoring sub-component of the project (RECETOX).

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Outline of National mercury reduction plan developed

baseline.comment:
No national mercury assessment made, except in form of waste product
No mercury action plan in place outlining priority action and setting budgetary allocations

target.comment:
Required data collected and analysed, and discussed in stakeholder forums
Priorities identified and agreed with stakeholders
Draft National Mercury Reduction plan is formally reviewed and cleared by relevant line Ministries and submitted for final approval.

actual.comment:
Inventory activity is ongoing.
Taking into account the policy of Kazakhstan to reduce the number of national policy documents, a decision was made during the Inception workshop instead of preparing a draft Mercury Reduction Plan to prepare recommendations for the reduction of mercury. This work is planned.
Project team participated in a regional IPEN meeting in Central Asia on public participation in chemical safety issues in EECCA countries. Following that meeting, and local consultations, a justification concept on Minamata convention ratification drafted and is prepared for submission to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs for review.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Public awareness raising campaigns on mercury risks conducted

baseline.comment: Low awareness of sources of mercury in consumer goods and consequences of their improper disposal.

target.comment: Remaining 50% of activities designed in the awareness campaign accomplished

actual.comment:
During 2014, four (4) national workshops were held where mercury issues were discussed (on par with the general POPs matters) in three (3) pilot provinces and the capital.
Three hundred (300) stakeholder representatives from government, health sector and industry improved their awareness on mercury management aspects and safety.

result.title: Outcome 3.1
result.description: Sound health-care waste management through uPOPs and mercury reduction approaches are demonstrated in 2-3 regions of the country

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Review of national policies and update of HCWM regulatory framework and road map

baseline.comment:
No comprehensive conceptual note on improving HCWM policies is in existence
No currently established emission standard for waste incineration (POPs, heavy metals).
No legal provisions exist, except minimum temperature standard for healthcare waste incineration.
No technical standards set for hazardous healthcare waste treatment, including non-combustion methods.
No current requirements defined for waste management plans and country budget does not consider non-incineration technologies for wider replication.
Public procurement rules do not include provisions on EPP (procured products can still contain heavy metals and other harmful substances), and the lowest price criterion is the main foundation.
Reporting systems (on waste amounts, tracking and monitoring) are underdeveloped

target.comment:
Legislative improvements (through amendments in the EcoCode) are submitted for final approval by the Government.
Technical standard for hazardous healthcare waste treatment, including non-combustion methods, is established in close consultations and forms a part of legislative improvements
Public procurement rules are amended and EPP criteria are set
Awareness raising workshops and media reports (at least, 3 complementary workshops for medical and private sectors, and 10 media reports)
National reporting to POPs convention improved

actual.comment:
An assessment of the current legislation on healthcare waste handling issues has been completed.
Project further evaluated the system of state cooperation in terms of accounting and disposal of healthcare waste; and assessed the environmental and sanitary-epidemiological requirements for healthcare waste handling.
Gaps have been revealed in the type of statistical information is being prepared and collected by the National Statistical Committee on HCW area. Various formats for data reporting are used in different provinces of the country – some hospitals report in kgs, tons or in unit measures.
In this respect, it is planned to develop proposals for changes in the national statistical system and industry reporting, with one unified reporting mechanism and format to ensure consistency and aid decision-making process in future.
Based on the regional healthcare waste management plans prepared for the three (3) pilot regions, the project will prepare, after pilot investment part with new technologies has been demonstrated, a summary report for the health/sanitary authorities to request consideration to replicate these pilots on a wider scale in the country. This will form a basis for the development of a unified national concept on healthcare waste management.
Further, after that step, project plans to incorporate its recommendations into a national municipal waste management plan which will raise the status of medical wastes to that strategic level.
The current decree # 26 of January 2015 (Ministry of Energy), prepared on the basis of the project’s intervention, sets emission standards for dioxins/furans. Additionally, amendments to the Environmental Code (regarding emission standards for dioxins/furans) have been proposed by the project team.
The previous governmental resolution of 2007 which set basic principles related to hazardous waste management, after legal reform, was transposed into a Ministry of Energy decree of November 28, 2014. This decree listed disposal technologies, on the basis of EU references, which covered wastewater discharges, releases from mining activities. It is now planned to introduce changes to the list of BAT and incorporate information on technologies related to healthcare waste disposal.
Proposals for amendments to the legislation on public procurement have been prepared and include environmental considerations, to be added to standard cost considerations in the legislation. This work is done jointly with a parallel GEF-UNDP project on energy-efficiency which deals in part with mercury waste coming out of CFL lamps. These amendments are hoped for introduction into a main law on public procurement in 2016.
Finally on legislation, as of May 4, 2015 project introduced amendments to previous governmental resolutions related to sanitary rules as applied to hospital operation. These authorize the use of needle cutters, and of alternative non-combustion waste disposal methods.
Four (4) regional training workshops were conducted on issues related to the management of POPs, including new POPs in three pilot provinces (300 participants in total).
The project made an economic analysis of the existing healthcare waste disposal system as well as those of alternative disposal methods proposed by the project. Certain maintenance issues were faced by owners of previously supplied non-incineration equipment (microwave technology with embedded shredder) due to frequent failures of the cutting blade – replacement costs are high. These problems were voiced during workshops.
This material, and the establishment of non-combustion centers for treatment of medical waste in three pilot areas, will create a good foundation for future development of such system on a wider scale in the country.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Development of Regional HCWM Management Plan in selected provinces

baseline.comment:
Baseline situation indicates no concerted action with adherence to BAT/BEP in medical sector
Sector is fragmented with disorganized players with no systemic approach to resolving uPOPs, mercury issues and inappropriate HCWM practices.
No specifically tailored action plan exists, and quality data is missing.
No previous capacity building and demonstration of BAT/BEP to reduce uPOPs and mercury releases implemented

target.comment:
The Management Plan is adopted, and further actions and investments scheduled
Roadmap to support its implementation is approved by participating stakeholders

actual.comment:
Based on technical advice from international expert, the project team had designed Healthcare Waste Management Plans for three selected pilot areas (Kostanay, Astana, and Ust-Kamenogorsk).
These plans include description of currently used healthcare waste management system, proposed alternative ways to improve practices through waste segregation (including the use of needle cutters to reduce accidents at work, and separate out plastic parts for disinfection).
It is expected that these plans will be introduced into the strategic regional development plans later in 2015 to ensure they are put into practical implementation.
An assessment of the waste generation volumes and decontamination of infectious healthcare waste across the country as a whole has been completed. And, in selected pilot areas this assessment has been implemented in 16 regions of the country, and in all state-funded hospitals and medical facilities. 154 medical facilities (2,761 beds) were assessed in the pilot regions.
The project further plans for preparation of recommendations to improve the reporting system of waste generation levels, demonstrate replacement of current basic incinerators for healthcare waste treatment with the alternative non-incineration technology, and of mercury thermometers with mercury-free alternatives (electronic measurement devices).
Data collection and analysis with regards to the treatment technologies for infectious healthcare waste in the pilot regions has been concluded. All incineration plants and plants processing infectious healthcare waste in the pilot regions have been identified and mapped.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Pilot HCWM projects in selected hospitals, including phase-out of mercury containing thermometers

baseline.comment:
No target hospitals for pilots defined before baseline assessment.
Waste minimization and segregation at source not practiced
No alternative (non-mercury) thermometers and alternative product substitution demonstrated
No model facilities (with individual action plans) pilot sustainable BAT/BEP and reduction in waste generation and uPOPs/mercury releases
BAT/BEP are not up taken on a larger scale
Overall waste management system is weak

target.comment:
BAT/BEP (uPOPs and mercury reduction) policies are implemented and targets recorded.
Mercury thermometers are replaced by electronic devices, with resulting mercury waste safely handled
Health facilities dispose IHCW in non-combustion installation.
Evaluation and documentation of practical results (inclusive of waste amounts minimized, uPOPs/mercury releases reduced) in conjunction with Outcome 4

actual.comment:
Three pilot areas have been identified (Ust-Kamenogorsk East Kazakhstan oblast, Kostanai oblast and Astana city). Eight (8) pilot hospitals have been selected: Astana (Research Institute of Traumatology and Orthopedics, Central Road Hospital), East-Kazakhstan oblast (CSE on EAR "Center of Mother and Child"; CSE on EAR Ust-Kamenogorsk city hospital 1, CSE on EAR "Central District Hospital of Katonkaragay District"), and Kostanay oblast (CSE on EAR Kostanai Drug Dispensary; SCCE “Oblast Hospital”; SCCE “Zhitigarinskaya CDH”.
A baseline assessment for each pilot hospital has been conducted using the individual Rapid Assessment (I-RAT) tool developed under the Global Medical Waste project as well as the "Guidelines for conducting a baseline assessment of an experienced medical institution". A registry (database) of hospitals in pilot regions has been created, and collection of data has been carried out in all hospitals of the pilot regions (154 facilities - 2,761 beds).
During reporting period, the project team assessed at the pilot sites their methods for healthcare waste treatment; and determined, based on guidance from assigned international expert with field visits, processing capacities (and design: with or w/o steam generator, shredder) required for each pilot hospital/healthcare facility.
ITB for procurement of non-incineration technologies (six 100 kg/h autoclaves, two 20 kg/h autoclaves for distant districts, and 1 more potential 20 kg/h autoclave if in case budget allows) are planned for formulation for the second half of 2015 to supply technology in 2016.
Healthcare waste management (HCWM) plans have been developed for the three (3) pilot regions, and project is actively working on getting these HCWM plans approved and the inclusion of main indicators/priorities into the strategic regional development documents for the target pilot areas.
A tender for the procurement of mercury-free thermometers will be soon announced. It is planned to procure 15,000 units of these electronic substitutes.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Establishment of HCW treatment centres in selected sites

baseline.comment:
Overall waste management system is weak
Health facilities have no access to organised waste treatment system or the waste is incinerated in installations not fulfilling BEP/BAT criteria.
No non-incineration technologies procured and adopted to support new management system in selected regions
Waste disposal and transportation of waste in peripheral areas (away from municipal or capital centers) is disadvantaged due to high price
Low quality of service provision results in additional sanitary risks

target.comment:
HCW treatment centres successfully operate at preliminary planned capacity (950 tons per annum).
Pricing policies implemented at target groups of stakeholders and service providers
Applicable recommendations on possible pricing criteria proposed for legislative amendments
Waste reduction amounts and uPOPs reductions are measured and reported on

actual.comment:
Tenders to open in the second half of 2015. Activities planned in the next reporting cycles.
Project plans the development of a proposal for setting tariffs on safe disposal of health-care wastes.

result.title: Outcome 3.2
result.description: Linkages between sound HCWM practices and minimization of uPOPs and mercury demonstrated through training and awareness raising programmes

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Development and dissemination of BAT/BEP technical guidelines and general awareness raising

baseline.comment:
No technical BAT/BEP guidelines in line with international benchmarks (SC, BC) for uPOPs/mercury release reduction and HCW management in place
No guidance materials for data collection and processing
Hospitals do not have guidance materials in support of trainings and daily safe practices
General awareness on uPOPs/mercury and management is limited

target.comment:
Technical guidelines approved and printed (legislative support to back guidelines proposed)
Hospitals receive materials for application in daily work
Project team participates in scientific medical conferences (at least, 2), public campaigns (media reports, at least 5, interviews, at least, 3), Zhasyl Damuu programme discussions and rountables
National curricula updated

actual.comment:
Introduction of changes to the existing list of best-available technologies (BAT) for treatment and disposal of healthcare waste is planned. Current legislation that refers to BAT technologies excludes this area of work, and will be amended in 2016 with a new list.
As part of South-South cooperation and experience exchange, project team participated in the GIZ-funded international conference for Central Asia, Afghanistan and other countries on biological hazard safety and protection in the neighboring, Kyrgyzstan in October 2014, shared its experience and exchanged with the Kyrgyzstan team (a parallel GEF-UNDP project on HCWM) on best practices.
The project team has started initial planning for design and development of a training module on healthcare waste management which will be discussed in the Ministry of health in future for application in medical colleges and universities. Further progress in this area will be reported in future reporting cycles.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Development of national training programs on uPOPs/mercury risks and sound HCWM, partnership with stakeholders and national replication of BAT/BEP demonstration

baseline.comment:
Currently, no HCW management training program exists as established by MPH
No manuals specifying details of waste management in a hospital setting exist
Limited in scope debriefings are practiced for new hospital staff, but no regular capacity building is in place or regularly planned by hospital facilities

target.comment:
Training carried in two demonstration regions for major health facilities, regional administration, and waste management service providers.
Training carried in 12 regions for major health facilities, and regional administration and integrated into national training system
Training program adopted and replicated by health institutions.
Media follows the initiative

actual.comment:
Four (4) regional training workshops were conducted on issues related to the management of POPs, including new POPs in three pilot provinces of the country for territorial municipal, health, sanitary and environmental control administrations, including hospitals, as well as for central authorities and industrial associations (300 participants in total).
Three (3) posts in online newspapers, and two (2) broadcasts on national TV; one (1) article was posted in a newspaper Kostanay Agro (one of pilot provinces), and in last edition of 2014 of a national magazine “Industry of Kazakhstan”.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Monitoring, learning, adaptive feedback, outreach, and evaluation.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: M&E and adaptive management applied to project in response to needs, mid-term evaluation findings with lessons learned extracted.

baseline.comment:
No Monitoring and Evaluation system
No evaluation of project output and outcomes

target.comment: Final evaluation report ready in the end of project

actual.comment:
Project activities, work plan and budget for the 2014/2015 were discussed and approved during the board meetings which took place in April 2014; July 2014; and January 2015.
Mid-term evaluation will be planned at time of the second PIR reporting exercise in line with UNDP-GEF Evaluation Office’s recommendations.
As part of South-South cooperation and experience exchange, project team participated in the GIZ-funded international conference for Central Asia, Afghanistan and other countries on biological hazard safety and protection in the neighboring, Kyrgyzstan in October 2014, shared its experience and exchanged with the Kyrgyzstan team (a parallel GEF-UNDP project on HCWM) on best practices.
Project team also participated in a regional IPEN meeting in Central Asia (held in Almaty, Kazakhstan) on public participation in chemical safety issues in EECCA countries.
